PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification;

We call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to introduce substantive legislation to ban X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) and to refuse classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that today's Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures show that capital expenditure by manufacturers in the September quarter of 1988, at $1.67 billion in seasonally adjusted terms, was 3 per cent lower than for the same period last year? Is it also a fact that overall investment expectations for the current financial year have been revised downwards? Does the Minister agree that this investment scenario does not augur well for Australia's productive capacity and its ability to become truly internationally competitive, as the Minister himself last week said was the test that counts? I further ask the Minister: When will the Government stop its self-congratulation and take action to change those many elements of the economic environment which put Australian business at a disadvantage against international competition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator Chaney does not expect me to answer the last part of the question, because international competition is dependent on various factors in various countries just as any sense of competitive advantage here is dependent on particular factors. So I decline to make that comparison at Question Time. However, I appreciate the point of the honourable senator's question. If I might say so, I think it would be premature to start talking about a downturn in investment activity. It is true that the ABS September quarter figures released today record a drop of 2.9 per cent which follows five successive quarters of increasing capital expenditure levels. Despite the decline in the September quarter, investment expenditure overall was 8.2 per cent above the level a year earlier. Moreover, the September quarter result is based only on preliminary data and is prone to substantial revision. I suspect that Senator Chaney will know that the preliminary results for both the March and June quarters of this year were also negative but that revised figures confirmed that positive growth had taken place in each of those quarters.

ANSWER.PARA: The revised 1987-88 outcome shows that in constant prices total investment in that year rose by 9.8 per cent compared with 7.2 per cent in the previous year; investment on plant and equipment rose by 8.3 per cent compared with 3.5 per cent in 1986-87; and manufacturing investment overall rose by 9.3 per cent in the year. At the same time, expectations data from the same ABS survey-this is one that Senator Chaney referred to-revealed that business investment growth is expected to be extremely strong in 1988-89. Those figures confirm the Treasurer's Budget projection of a real increase in business investment of around 12 per cent. I conclude by saying, as I have said on other occasions, that there is no cause for complacency in those figures but I think there is no cause for optimism on behalf of anyone-I am not putting Senator Chaney in this category-who would wish to say that they were serious.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the Minister for his answer but I would like to ask a supplementary question on that curious part of his answer in which he referred to international competitiveness being dependent on particular factors and declined to comment. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that Australia's inflation rate is very much out of line with the rates of our international competitors at 7.3 per cent, being about double the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, nearly double that of the United States, about 15 times that of Japan and six times that of Germany? Is he aware that nominal wage rises are running at 6 per cent in Australia compared with about half that in the United States and Japan and just over half that in Germany? Is he aware that prime interest rates in this country are very high on any international comparison? Does he accept that they are all relevant matters-indeed, there are many others; for example, the condition of our transport system and waterfront-which go to the capacity of Australians to be internationally competitive, as he is constantly exhorting them to be? What is the Government proposing to do to change these fundamentals, which are so much to the disadvantage of Australian manufacturers and other investors?

—First of all, let me say that I agree with Senator Chaney's figures in terms of the inflation rates in various countries, but in his supplementary question he gave a classic example of what I mean when, for example, he singled out increases in nominal wage rates. We are often urged to be competitive with the United Kingdom. Nominal wage rates in the United Kingdom have increased considerably more than ours and one can, country by country--
—You are not pointing to the United Kingdom--
—No, I agree with that, but one can go from country to country and make comparisons of various--
—Try Taiwan.

—I am not going to Taiwan. Let me say that, in terms of both industrial relations and wage rates, the Taiwanese economy has become less competitive in the last six months. In so far as Senator Chaney mentions other questions like the transport system, the waterfront and so on, the Government is addressing those issues. Solutions are not going to happen overnight. We have said that on a number of occasions. We expect the inflation rate to be down by the middle of next year. If it is not down, Senator Chaney will be able to ask me another question about it.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: Is he aware of Australian participation in a planned regional peace brigade to the Philippines to protest the presence of United States military bases in that country. Does the Government have any comment on such participation in the light of the situation in the Philippines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of reports that Australians, including, I think, Senator Vallentine, intend participating in a regional peace brigade to the Philippines for approximately one month from late December to protest or demonstrate against United States military facilities there. Philippine authorities have expressed concern to our Embassy in Manila on two counts: firstly, that violence could be provoked at the demonstrations in order to embarrass the Philippines Government; and, secondly, over the possibility of contact by Australians with illegal groups in the Philippines.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to remind people that travel in parts of the Philippines can be dangerous and to reiterate the existing consular travel advice that has been put out by my Department with respect to the Philippines which advises Australians to avoid inessential travel to the areas surrounding the Clark air force base and the Subic naval base and also reminds Australians that contact with proscribed organisations in the Philippines, including the Communist Party of the Philippines, the New People's Army and the National Democratic Front, makes them liable to prosecution under Philippine law.

The Australian Government has also made it clear to the Philippine authorities that the Government looks to them to ensure that forces under their control do not exceed their authority in enforcing applicable Philippine law. I think it is also prudent to remind those Australians who enter the Philippines on tourist visas that any breach of the provisions or the conditions on which these visas are issued could result in action being taken against them by Philippine authorities. I have no intention whatever of questioning the right of Australian citizens to express their views on issues of concern to them. However, they have a responsibility in their own interests to ensure that their participation in public demonstrations in a foreign country is within the laws of that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney- General been drawn to the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald concerning the involvement of Wardley Australia Ltd, to the tune of over $160m, in the original Rothwells Ltd rescue plan? The article mentions that `Wardley executives who contacted potential investors stressed the Government guarantee, and that as the State was installing its own managing director, contributors would be supporting virtually a semi-government authority'. As it was on this basis that a number of Australia's largest companies agreed to contribute to the Rothwells rescue plan, is the Government concerned to see this aspect of the Rothwells affair investigated by the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC)? As the implicit and explicit guarantees by the Western Australian Government were likely to form part of the marketing of the Wardley financial package, will the NCSC examine this deal to determine the authenticity of the guarantees and the way they were used and promoted to persuade parties to agree to the rescue package? Given this new development, and the fact that corporations and small shareholders alike invested in Rothwells on the strength of the Western Australian Government's guarantees, will the Government reconsider its position and call immediately a royal commission into the entire Rothwells affair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the Government will not be reconsidering its decision at the moment in relation to the question of Rothwells and the proper investigations that might be undertaken in relation to its collapse. I have not read the article concerning Wardley Australia. So, I am unable to comment on the contents of the special article to which Senator Messner referred. I must say, as I said only yesterday in this chamber, that the National Companies and Securities Commission has undertaken to conduct an investigation under section 36 of the relevant legislation. I believe that gives the National Companies and Securities Commission sufficient and adequate powers of a wide ranging kind to summon witnesses, to require production of documents and to take evidence on oath. That will well place it to carry out the sorts of inquiries that are required in light of the fact, as Mr Bosch himself indicated, that the NCSC has reason to suspect that offences, being offences under the companies and securities legislation and offences that involve fraud or dishonesty or concern at the management of Rothwells Ltd and companies associated with it, may have been committed.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a most serious situation. The National Companies and Securities Commission clearly believes, at the moment, that it has sufficient power and scope under section 36 to undertake a proper and adequate investigation. The fact is that the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities, as I mentioned yesterday, meets later this week-I think in Canberra. I have no doubt that Mr Bosch and his officers will be reporting to the Ministerial Council in relation to this matter. Obviously it would be at the Ministerial Council that the adequacy of this particular approach could be determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to ask a supplementary question. Does not the Minister think that there is something fishy about a situation in which the Western Australian Government was invited to place its guarantee on a rescue plan being put in place, but withdrew its guarantee, and in which a Minister of the Government claimed that any investor in Rothwells Ltd must have been dumb, blind, illiterate or out of the country?
—I am confident that all aspects of this affair will be fully exposed within the framework of the investigation being undertaken by the National Companies and Securities Commission.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Minister read a letter from Duncan Bell, the Executive Director of the Australian Gold Mining Industry Council, to the Editor of the Australian Financial Review, which letter was published this morning, admitting an inequity between the present treatment of income derived from the mining of gold and income derived from other sources? What is Mr Bell's proposed solution to this inequity? Will the Government be adopting it? What are the implications of this proposal for revenue and, in turn, outlays?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a letter in the Australian Financial Review today with Mr Bell's name on it. I also saw on Saturday a full page advertisement, I think it was in the Sydney Morning Herald, with Mr Bell's name on it in which he was lobbying for another group, the superannuation industry. I note for the record that Mr Bell anticipates his disemployment because the question of the special tax break for goldmining will, of course, be put to bed forever within a couple of months. Mr Bell will no longer have a job. He is now working as a lobbyist for another tax break industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Today's letter said:

Because the dramatic expansion of the Australian gold mining industry has been promoted by the current taxation system applying to the industry, what the gold miners are now saying to the Government is you've got the system right on gold mining.
Mr Bell continued:
If you want both equity and industrial growth, use this system as a proven model for the basis for reform of the general corporation taxation.

In other words, Mr Bell is saying that corporate tax should be abolished. Whatever case there may be for the abolition of corporate tax does not apply to the total exemption from taxation of extractive industries like goldmining. This is something that I notice even the Queensland Government got right because it imposes a significant tax on goldmining, notwithstanding its pontifications about the inequity of the Commonwealth Government doing the same thing. The implication of the abolition of corporate tax is that more than $10 billion would be lost to revenue in this financial year, which is almost 12 per cent of Commonwealth revenue and more than 12 per cent of Commonwealth outlays. So, to maintain the same degree of fiscal discipline, it would therefore be necessary to cut outlays by 12.4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that take into account the extra income tax that would be paid? Is that a net or gross figure?

—It is a gross figure. If one accepts that it is not possible to cut outlays on public debt interest, defence pensions, all personal benefit payments and the financial assistance grants to the States and Territories, that would require cutting 41 per cent of all other Commonwealth outlays-which I suggest is an absurd proposition. Further to Senator Chaney's query, if all company income were distributed as dividends the loss to revenue after the time lag of probably a year would not be all that great. But, of course, it is not all distributed as dividends and there would be a year's time lag in any case.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that the Liberal Party has sided with the tax bludgers on this issue and has taken the view that the present policy should be maintained in perpetuity, I would be interested to hear the ideas of Senator Chaney, Mr Peacock or Mr Howard about whether the logic in the goldminers' argument should be extended to its conclusion; that is, the abolition of all corporate taxation. If the Opposition is going to advocate that, I would be interested to hear what adjustments Dr Hewson proposes to make on the outlays side of the Budget in order to maintain the same degree of fiscal discipline.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of a survey of Australia's leading corporations conducted by the Australian newspaper which showed that Australia's six largest corporate borrowers between them owed $26 billion-equal to more than 23 per cent of Australia's gross foreign debt? Does the Minister agree that the increasing preference for raising capital through debt rather than through equity is due to the fact that debt is cheaper because it is tax deductable? Will the Minister provide an estimate of how much tax revenue has been lost since 1984 because private companies are allowed to claim their foreign borrowings as a tax deduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the survey; that is the answer to the first part of the question. In response to the second part of the question, I think I have made this point in the Senate before but it is worth making again: fashions change. In the 1960s it was a bilateral political position in Australia-it would even have been trilateral had the Australian Democrats been around at that time, I suggest-that we should restrict the amount of foreign equity, particularly in large mining projects. Given the limited size of the capital market, it then followed inevitably either that mining projects would not proceed or that they would have to have a high gearing ratio. They proceeded in the main on money borrowed from foreign banks. That was held-particularly, probably, by the `Left' of Australian politics-as being a very appropriate policy.

ANSWER.PARA: By the 1980s, however, the fashion had been completely reversed, and equity was to be preferred to debt-especially foreign debt. My own view is that there is something to be said for that, because a country which has a high level of foreign debt is more exposed than one which has a high level of foreign owned equity. If there is a downturn and the foreigners own equity, the foreigners go without their dividends. But if they are owed loans they continue to collect their interest. For that reason, I think that our exposure to foreign debt, as distinct from foreign equity, has made us somewhat more vulnerable. That was particularly the case in 1986. I do not know what is the cost to revenue, if any, of the conversion of equity to debt. I doubt whether there are any reliable estimates, but I will ask the Treasurer about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice able to inform the Senate of the scope of the special reference given to the National Crime Authority in relation to alleged crime and corruption in South Australia?
—I asked that question yesterday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promised that I would do my best to inform Senator Hill and other honourable senators of the answer. That is exactly what I intend to do. The fact is that a reference has been granted to the National Crime Authority by the intergovernmental committee of Ministers-they are drawn from all over Australia-responsible for the operations of the National Crime Authority, when it undertakes an exercise of its special coercive powers in order to advance an investigation into particularly serious offences.
—This looks like a case for incorporation.
—I do intend to incorporate some material in a moment.
—Why couldn't you answer this yesterday?
—I will tell Senator Hill why I could not answer it yesterday in a moment.
—Order! I ask Senator Tate to ignore the interjections.

—Yes, Mr President, I will. The fact is that the South Australian Government has been seeking the presence of a National Crime Authority office in South Australia in order to advance the investigation into allegations of crime and corruption. Indeed, I believe that the decision taken by the intergovernmental committee late last week is testimony to that fact. The fact is that a highly qualified and experienced barrister from outside South Australia has been approached. He has indicated a preparedness to undertake the appointment. That appointment will be made as soon as possible after this Parliament passes legislation in order to enable an additional member to be appointed to the National Crime Authority. The office will then be established. It will comprise counsel assisting, seconded lawyers and accountants, special investigators, surveillance officers, intelligence analysts, seconded police officers and administrative and other support staff.
—Are you going to give us the terms of reference?

—In regard to the terms of reference-the scope of the matter referred to the National Crime Authority-I was asked yesterday by Senator Hill about this and I indicated in good faith that I would wish to make those terms of reference available, but I felt it incumbent upon me to consult with the National Crime Authority as it has never been done previously. Nevertheless, I have had those conversations with Mr Lionel Robberds, a member of the National Crime Authority, this morning. He concurs with my proposal to table, perhaps to incorporate, those terms of reference. In essence, the matter for investigation involves looking at the nature and scope of any illegal activity, the identity of the persons involved and the nature of their involvement disclosed by the circumstances or allegations described below or otherwise revealed by investigations into those circumstances or allegations. The particulars are:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The general nature of the circumstances or allegations constituting the relevant criminal activities is activity by groups of persons members of whom were identified to the South Australian Minister by the Authority on the 24th of November 1988 and associated persons and companies suggesting offences involving:
(i) bribery or corruption of, or by, police officers and other officers of the State of South Australia;
(ii) illegal gambling, extortion and prostitution;
(iii) the cultivation, manufacture, preparation or supply of drugs of addiction, prohibited drugs or other narcotic substances;
(iv) murder and attempted murder.
(b) The offences referred to above are, or include, offences against laws of the State of South Australia.
(c) The purpose of the investigation is:

(i) to ascertain whether any or what relevant offences (including any offence deemed to be a relevant offence pursuant to section 3 (3) of the National Crime Authority (State Provisions) Act 1984 (S.A.)) have been or are being committed against laws of the State of South Australia;
(ii) to identify the offender or offenders;
(iii) to assemble evidence that would be admissible in the prosecution of the offenders;
(iv) to furnish that evidence to the Attorney-General of the State of South Australia or to the relevant law enforcement agency for the prosecution of those offences.
Mr President, for the complete satisfaction of honourable senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the names that were in it yesterday?

—As I indicated in my answer yesterday, the names of the persons who are the targets, if you like, in the investigation are not known even to me and are not known to other Ministers on the intergovernmental committee.
—You said you could not table it yesterday because of the names.
—The honourable senator will not find any names in this document.
—You said yesterday that was why you could not disclose it. So there weren't any names?
—No, I was not going to disclose the terms of reference at all. In disclosing these terms of reference there will be found to be no names of targets for the investigation.

Indeed, as I say, those names are known only between the relevant Minister, being the Minister in South Australia, and the National Crime Authority. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the terms of reference of this special investigation to be undertaken by the National Crime Authority in South Australia.

TO: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

PURSUANT to Sub-section 5 (1) of the NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (STATE PROVISIONS) Act, 1984 (S.A.), I HEREBY REFER to the National Crime Authority for investigation the following matters relating to relevant criminal activities insofar as the relevant offence or the relevant offences are or include an offence or offences against the law of the State of South Australia.
MATTERS

The nature and scope of any illegal activity, the identity of the persons involved and the nature of their involvement disclosed by the circumstances or allegations described below or otherwise revealed by investigations into those circumstances or allegations.
PARTICULARS PURSUANT TO SUB-SECTION 5 (3) NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (STATE PROVISIONS) ACT 1984 (S.A.)

(a) The general nature of the circumstances or allegations constituting the relevant criminal activities is activity by groups of persons members of whom were identified to me by the Authority on the 24th of November 1988 and associated persons and companies suggesting offences involving:
(i) bribery or corruption of, or by, police officers and other officers of the State of South Australia;
(ii) illegal gambling, extortion and prostitution;
(iii) the cultivation, manufacture, preparation or supply of drugs of addiction, prohibited drugs or other narcotic substances;
(iv) murder and attempted murder.
(b) The offences referred to above are, or include, offences against laws of the State of South Australia.
(c) The purpose of the investigation is:

(i) to ascertain whether any or what relevant offences (including any offence deemed to be a relevant offence pursuant to section 3 (3) of the National Crime Authority (State Provisions) Act 1984 (S.A.)) have been or are being committed against laws of the State of South Australia;
(ii) to identify the offender or offenders;
(iii) to assemble evidence that would be admissible in the prosecution of the offenders;
(iv) to furnish that evidence to the Attorney-General of the State of South Australia or to the relevant law enforcement agency for the prosecution of those offences.
Dated this 24th day of November 1988.
D. J. Hapgood
Minister of Emergency Services
for the State of South Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, relates to the planned shipment of spent nuclear fuel rods from Lucas Heights to be undertaken by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO). How does the Minister explain the obvious conflict of interest in this case, which arises from the fact that ANSTO is both the client plus the independent regulatory authority advising the body responsible for checking that the LHRL cask complies with relevant standards and regulations? Given the lack of expertise in Australia, apart from ANSTO, does the Minister intend appointing an independent and qualified inspector from any other source to check the ANSTO cask and to investigate the current claims of poor design and manufacture? If not, why not? What are the relevant qualifications and experience of the Department of Transport and Communications officers responsible for approving the design of the cask, who approved their appointment to carry out this task and what qualifications and experience did the authorisers have? Finally, did the inspectors check the LHRL cask against the design plans on its arrival in Australia? What is the nature of the inspection and handling trials now being undertaken? Specifically, were all the welds on the fuel baskets inspected on arrival in Australia to ensure that they conformed to welds specified on the design drawings? If such an inspection took place, were any discrepancies discovered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been the subject of some press comment and I have been waiting with bated breath for 10 days now for Senator Vallentine to come back to the Senate and ask this question. First of all, the Department of Transport and Communications is the competent Australian authority under the appropriate international code, which is the International Maritime and Dangerous Goods Code, relating to the sea transport of all hazardous materials from Australia, including radioactive materials. In relation to structural aspects of standards under the code for the spent fuel cask, qualified Department of Transport and Communications engineers-that is, qualified under the code-have vetted the cask design and have confirmed that it meets the design criteria, as has the United States Department of Transportation. ANSTO has no regulatory responsibility in respect of the cask so there is no conflict of interest there, as implied in the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission was consulted by the United States Department of Transportation in relation to revalidation of the Australian certificate of approval and assurance of a competent authority certificate. The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission evaluation of the safety analysis report prepared by the designers drew attention to three design assumptions relating to one accident test situation and stated that large margins exist between the stress calculations and the design criteria. So the combined corrected calculations would not significantly reduce the shielding effectiveness.

The style of media reporting of this event draws unwarranted attention to a few items taken out of context. For example, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission confirmed that the cask meets the applicable requirements of the International Atomic Energy Agency regulations and recommended that the certificates be issued. There is no reason to have any further independent inspection. I just make the point, because it has also been the subject of newspaper comment, that some casks have been withdrawn from use in the United States. They are old ones designed and built years ago. This is simply an example of updated safety requirements being applied.

The implication in some press reports and in Senator Vallentine's question is that the ANSTO cask is similar to old withdrawn models in the United States. That is entirely wrong. The ANSTO cask was built to current standards and was completed only this year. It was checked against the approved design by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the United States, at the request of the Australian Department of Transport and Communications, before it left the United States. Officers of the Department of Transport and Communications and ANSTO are continuing to undertake a series of performance and acceptance tests, such as vacuum leak testing, and to familiarise relevant ANSTO staff with the handling of the cask and its associated specialist tooling.

—Is the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of general concern about the use of the drug depo-provera, particularly in Aboriginal communities, where there is doubt that adequate efforts are being made to ensure fully informed consent? What steps are being taken to review the circumstances under which depo-provera is offered as a contraceptive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Depo-provera is marketed in Australia and approved for treatment of certain cancers. It is also used as a long-acting contraceptive injection that is effective for several months. However, it is important to remember that depo-provera is not specifically approved for use as a contraceptive. But, as it is marketed, there is no legal impediment to prescribing it for contraceptive purposes. This means that those receiving it should be very aware of its status as an investigational drug and that consent for its use, preferably in writing, should always be obtained.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of organisations around Australia, such as the Victorian Coalition against Depo-provera and the Family Planning Association, have expressed considerable reservations about the overuse of depo-provera, particularly in Aboriginal communities. To this effect I wrote to the Queensland Minister for Health. I had received a number of complaints from Queensland about the overuse of depo-provera in remote communities, particularly Aboriginal communities. Mrs Harvey said that the matter had been investigated and that she was advised that a modest number of women, mainly but not only Aboriginal or Islander women, in north Queensland currently are receiving depo-provera every three months for contraceptive purposes, the drug being prescribed by medical practitioners and patients being counselled about the use of the drug and its possible complications. She advised that until recently verbal consent was obtained from the patients prior to administration of the drug but that it is now usual to obtain written consent. I am certainly pleased to hear that written consent is now usually-she uses the word `usually'-obtained. I think we should ensure that all medical practitioners obtain that written consent.

I am advised by Dr Blewett that the Chairman of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee has agreed to seek new data from the drug's manufacturer and plans to consider that information, as well as information provided by a number of other groups, such as the Family Planning Association and the Victorian Coalition against Depo-provera, to reassess the drug's current status as investigational. Furthermore, the ethics of prescribing an investigational drug are being considered by the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. It has recently agreed to prepare ethical guidelines to address the circumstances of prescribing an investigational drug in situations other than an outside, controlled clinical environment.

Australian women who have any reservations about the prescribing of depo-provera should ask themselves and their doctors whether those doctors would prescribe depo-provera for themselves, in the case of female doctors and whether they would prescribe the drug for their wives or daughters. There certainly is considerable concern about the way in which this drug has been used, particularly in relation to Aboriginal communities, Islander communities and other communities in remote areas where perhaps there is not the same necessary awareness of its investigational status.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the reply by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to my question of 28 September in which he indicated that the arms control and disarmament elements in President Gorbachev's speech at Krasnoyarsk on 16 September were being studied by the Government. Given that the Minister promised a more detailed response to the speech that he gave at the time, I ask the Minister: Firstly, is he aware that Soviet officials at a recent conference in Vladivostok stated that the SS-N21 sea-launched nuclear cruise missile was not being deployed in the Pacific as part of the nuclear freeze outlined in the Krasnoyarsk speech? Secondly, can the Minister also confirm that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) has ceased testing long range ballistic missiles in the Pacific? Thirdly, given that the Government opposes any trade-off between Soviet bases in Vietnam and American bases in the Philippines, does the Government foresee any circumstances in which foreign military bases are removed from the Asia-Pacific region? Fourthly, if not, does the Government support the indefinite presence of the United States in the region irrespective of whether the USSR stays on at Cam Ranh Bay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I think I have said before, the Government welcomes the various indications, including those contained in the Krasnoyarsk speech, that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is seeking more constructive involvement in the Pacific region. Our own position on the kind of arms control disarmament proposals that are emerging is shaped by three basic considerations. The first is that the north Pacific is second only to Europe in terms of deployed military capability. Secondly, there is no established framework for security negotiations in this region. Thirdly, these issues are of direct concern to regional states. Our own proposals, such as they are, in response to these concerns and considerations, have essentially been confined to urging greater transparency and greater dialogue on security concerns. This represents starting at the beginning. I do not pretend that any more elaborate set of prescriptions has yet been worked out.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of our response to specific questions raised by Senator Macklin, as to the sea-launched nuclear cruise missile deployment issue, the nuclear freeze proposal was outlined in the Krasnoyarsk speech. The proposal not to increase the amount or the number of any nuclear weapons in the region was a noteworthy one. We acknowledge it as such. The difficulty about it, particularly in the context I have just mentioned of the cruise missiles, is that it is essentially unverifiable in character, to the extent that the SSN21 can be fired from torpedo tubes and could be deployed on most submarines. That is a fundamental flaw in any disposition we might otherwise have to take at face value that particular part of the proposal.

As to the second question about the USSR having ceased testing long range ballistic missiles in the Pacific, we are not aware that the USSR has declared an end to testing such ballistic missiles into the Pacific, nor in fact that it has stopped doing so. To respond to the third part of Senator Macklin's question, we see no advantage in speculating as to the circumstances in which foreign military bases might be removed from the Asia-Pacific region. As to the fourth part of Senator Macklin's question, which asked whether we support the indefinite presence of the United States of America in the region irrespective of whether the USSR stays at Cam Ranh Bay, I suppose we say that the United States presence in the Asia-Pacific region is essentially a matter for the United States itself to resolve with the countries concerned. In so far as the question specifically intended to refer to United States bases in the Philippines, the clear Australian view which I, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence have spelt out on numerous occasions is that these bases are important to giving a sense of security to countries of the region. Our clear preference would be that they remain, which is a preference which is manifestly shared by the Association of South East Asian Nations itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. It relates to an answer given in the other place yesterday by the Minister for Social Security to a question regarding the introduction of the Child Support Agency when the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: The scheme is a complex one. It involves several agencies of the Government.

Does this excuse the lengthy delays that are being incurred in the collection and transfer of child maintenance payments as a result of a changeover from current collection agencies to the Child Support Agency scheme and of the considerable hardships that are being encountered by its beneficiaries? Is the Minister aware that because of interdepartmental bureaucracy there will be a time lag of some six weeks between the time maintenance payments are made to the Australian Taxation Office and the time that the beneficiary actually receives those payments from the Department of Social Security? Is the Minister aware that at the time of the actual changeover from previous collection agencies, such as the Department of Community Welfare in my own State of South Australia, to the Child Support Agency, this time lag will be stretched to some eight to 10 weeks? What does the Government intend to do about this problem in order to avoid undue hardship being placed upon those families in need, most especially during the festive season?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to the second part of Senator Chapman's question first. It is undeniable that what the Government is doing in implementing the Child Support Agency, and the principles behind that, is essentially and primarily to raise the living standards of a whole host of children in the community who otherwise have been neglected by the non-custodial parent. I think it is quite understood, if not on the other side of this Parliament then at least generally in the community, that those children have been neglected and that the mechanism the Government is putting in place is very important in terms of alleviating poverty in this sector. Also, we should understand not only the complexity of the scheme that has been introduced but also its magnitude. We estimate that, without restrictions, 200,000 additional persons could very well be eligible for maintenance collection in the initial year of operation. We should also understand that we are working with State and Territory governments and their collection agencies, and the Government has stated quite a number of times that we will gradually bring those agencies under the ambit of the scheme over a period of at least 12 months. ANSWER.PARA: I have said these things to put the whole question that Senator Chapman raised in its appropriate context. In respect of the specific points he made obviously I can pursue them further for him. But I say to the honourable senator: do not underestimate the value of the scheme and do not underestimate the complexity of the situation-which the Government is addressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister give some assurance, especially with the festive and holiday season imminent, that he will take immediate action to ensure that the hardships which people will be experiencing as a result of these delays are overcome?

—I can undertake to pursue the points Senator Chapman raised. It is quite obvious that it has never been the intention of this Government to cause hardship to people at any time of the year, let alone the one that he mentioned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ARMY PERSONNEL SERVING WITH THE UNITED NATIONS ON THE IRAN-IRAQ BORDER

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 November Senator Newman asked me a question on Army personnel serving with the United Nations forces on the Iran-Iraq border. I have an answer to that question. Members serving with the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group (UNIIMOG) are currently receiving a United Nations mission subsistence allowance. That allowance is $A197 a day for the first 30 days and $A185 a day thereafter. Although it is known in broad detail what the allowance covers, more precise details are being sought to enable a decision to be made as to whether supplementation through an Australian allowance should be introduced. In addition, a case is being developed for a disability allowance package. This could include a post allowance at the rate applicable to all government employees serving in Tehran. In addition, there could be elements to cover additional disabilities of service in the field and the hazardous nature of the duties. Evidence to support the case is still being collected. The decision on the overall package to be provided rests, of course, with the Minister for Industrial Relations. Both the initial outlay advance and the special outlay advance provided to UNIIMOG members must be repaid, as is normal in these situations.

ANSWER.PARA: The intention is that the package of allowances developed to cover service with UNIIMOG be paid while the duty is in progress, although this may be difficult to achieve for the first team deployed because of the lack of lead time before the group was sent overseas. Considerable delays have been experienced in obtaining sufficient information to support the proposed package of allowances. Communications with Iran are poor and the Australian United Nations military observers are fully occupied in their primary task, impeding data provision. However, additional information has recently been provided from Iran, and it is hoped that this will allow at least an interim decision to be made on the field element of the disability package. Every effort is being made to provide allowances for UNIIMOG members in the shortest time possible consistent with the requirement for responsibility in adopting new allowances. However, I repeat: the 15 Australian members of the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group are currently receiving the United Nations mission subsistence allowance.

INTERJECT.PARA: ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C-EXAMINATION OF ESTIMATES OF THE BUREAU OF STATISTICS

I apprehend that the discussion before the Committee of the matter of the Household Expenditure Survey of the Bureau of Statistics has left members of the Committee and other Senators with something of an incomplete impression of the part played by Senate officers in the examination by Senators of the survey. In order to correct any misapprehension I would like to place the following brief statement among the records of the Committee.

Certain Senators asked me to examine the question of whether the Household Expenditure Survey could be a compulsory survey in view of the fact that no proposal for the survey was laid before each House of the Parliament. I passed this request to Mr Peter O'Keeffe, Clerk-Assistant (Procedure), whose duty it is to provide advice on legislative matters to non-government Senators. He composed a brief memorandum indicating a view that failure to table a proposal prevented the survey being compulsory, and recommending that, if Senators wished to take further action, a further opinion be obtained. This memorandum was provided to the Senators concerned, and they requested a further opinion. The further opinion was obtained from Professor Douglas Whalan, and made available to the Senators. That opinion reached much the same conclusion as Mr O'Keeffe's. At the request of the Senators concerned, other aspects of the question in issue were examined by Mr O'Keeffe and Professor Whalan, and further opinions were obtained and provided to the Senators.

That was the extent of the involvement of Senate officers in the matter; they have done no more and no less than provide advice on legislative matters to Senators. They have not participated in the political controversy about the survey, contrary to some highly coloured press reports.

At page C139 of the Hansard transcript of the proceedings of the Committee there is reference to my correspondence with the Australian Statistician, Mr Castles, being provided to the Committee. As I do not know what correspondence has been provided, I think I should now present to the Committee a full set of copies of all the correspondence, and this full set of all copies is attached. I have included in the copies one letter to a Senator to indicate that an intention expressed in a letter to Mr Castles had been carried out. I make no comment on the correspondence, which, read in sequence, speaks for itself. The circumstances in which the correspondence was provided to certain Senators is explained in the correspondence.

I would be grateful if this letter were circulated to members of the Committee, the Minister and Senators who attended the Committee's hearing, and included in the additional material which the Committee customarily presents to the Senate.

I rise to speak to the review of the activities for 1987-88 of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Review `88 covers many important issues. I believe that it will be a very useful report as a source of reference for basic information in this area. Two of the changes that occurred during the period 1987-88 to which I would like to refer are the decentralisation of some services and the business migration scheme. The report states:
Structural changes to the Department's Central Office in December 1987 followed a decision to devolve most casework to State and Territory Offices.

In fact, since that time there has been a decentralisation of a great many services. This decentralisation has involved a lot of the activities which were formerly carried out only from Canberra and which are now carried out in the capitals of the various States. It has also meant that some of the services have moved away from central business districts and are now more accessible to clients in local suburban areas. I must say that in my own home State of Western Australia I know from personal experience that this has made a lot of difference to the clients in this area. The report refers to Western Australia on page 161 where it states:

There were continuing signs, as the year developed, that immigration workloads in the State Office in Perth would increase at a greater rate than any other single office of the Department in Australia.
This trend confirmed the reality that Western Australia proportionately has the largest migrant community.
I would like to turn to the subject of business migration, which is covered at some length in the report. It states:

The Business Migration Program seeks to attract people with a proven business background who intend to settle in Australia and who will use their skills and capital to establish ventures of benefit to Australia.
Procedures for processing applicants whose background and potential clearly meet the program objectives have been streamlined.
In 1987-88, a number of independent Australian business organisations and consultants were appointed as Accredited Business Migrant Agents . . .

As a result of such initiatives and continuing promotion overseas, Business Migration Program numbers have continued to climb. In 1987-88, visas were issued to 7387 people . . . The main source countries were Hong Kong (788 cases), Britain (169), Malaysia (165), Singapore (86), Indonesia (55) and Japan (67).

Be that as it may, there have been a lot of concerns expressed about the business migration scheme and these have been highlighted in the press and particularly in articles put out in the Sydney Morning Herald by the journalist Margo Kingston. There are some details that I think would be cause for grave anxiety. For example, the Sydney Morning Herald ran an article on a seminar held on business migration, at which the director of business migration in the Western Australian Government's Exim Corp., Ms Lesley Maher, warned that monitoring was vital. She stated:

Perhaps we will then stop the recycling of the $500,000 [where a migrant sends back his $500,000 for someone else to use to get their visa], and the failure of business migrants to go ahead with what they propose in statements of intent.
Again, it is stated in the Sydney Morning Herald:

Ms Anna-Maree Osborne, a partner in Overseas Business Ventures Australia, says the revolving $500,000 rort happens ``a lot''. She said a Chinese agent in Chinatown lent migrants $500,000 for a month at 30 per cent interest to get in. And an Indonesian client sent his $500,000 back home on the advice of his Australian bank manager. ``He was told it was stupid to keep it here and pay tax, and to send it back to Indonesia until he really needed it,''. . .

Western Australia has encouraged business migrants to put their half million dollars in an investment trust for up to five years until they start in business and during that time they are given free advice.

The various migrant groups in Australia have expressed grave concern about the business migration program. They feel that the migrants coming out under that program are not necessarily the sort of migrants who will make a go of it in Australia and that schemes, such as the family reunion scheme, under which migrants come out to join members of their own family and are determined to settle and make their lives here, are much sounder in the long run. I do not think that Australia really can afford to bring in people who are here merely to exploit us. I am well aware that not all business migrants come into that category, but I feel that privatising the scheme is not in the best interests of all Australians. It should be looked at and reviewed as fast as possible.

I am pleased to speak today to the annual report 1987-88 of the Australian Sports Commission and I think anyone with any interest in sport at all might be well advised to have a look at this report. It is very comprehensive, understandable and well presented. The foreword points out that the report is presented in accordance with the Australian Sports Commission Act 1985. The Commission's principal objectives are:
(a) to encourage the private sector to contribute to the funding of sport to supplement assistance by the Commonwealth;
(b) to provide leadership in the development of Australia's performance in sport; and
(c) to encourage increased participation by Australians in sport.

Through the pages of this report we can see the number of ways in which those objectives are being very adequately and comprehensively met. The area that I particularly want to pick up is women in sport, but I note in passing the Aussie Sports program which I have spoken about in this place and strongly endorsed. Some 500,000 young Australians are now registered as participants in that program. I think that is very commendable, particularly as that program was introduced not only to encourage children to try their hand at a lot of modified sports but also to get a lot of children to try sport at all. I think many of them in our schools had got used to not participating actively in sport, and the Aussie Sports program has reversed that trend.

Before I speak about women in sport I note also in the report a very detailed description of what the Commission is doing to address the problem of drugs in sport-another matter I have raised in this place in times past.

In the area of women in sport the report contains a neat summary of the history of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit. Many people here would know that when I came into this Parliament in 1984 I was asked to convene an inquiry into women in sport. We made a number of recommendations and that report was tabled in both Houses of Parliament in early 1985. Subsequent to that a Task Force for Women's Sport was established, chaired by the Australian Sports Commissioner, Margaret Pewtress. That task force was established in November 1986 and was funded to run until 30 June 1987 but its time was extended so as to allow the task force to complete the national policy and plan for women in sport.

In November 1987 the Women's Sports Promotion Unit, the principal recommendation of our report and certainly something that the Task Force for Women's Sport continued to promote, was established by the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown. The Australian Sports Commission has allocated an initial $50,000 for that Women's Sport Promotion Unit. On pages 52 and 53 of the report is a detailed description of the aims and objectives of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit and a list of many of its achievements to this point. One that I draw to the attention of the Senate is:
A television community service advertisement has been made with Film Australia for the promotion of women in sport.

I had the pleasure of inviting Senator Richardson to launch that advertisement at a function I hosted in South Australia. I am advised that that community service advertisement was used quite often in the intervals in the coverage of the Olympic Games. I cannot say that that happened in all States; I have not had reports on it. But I know that in Canberra it was shown very often and received a good response. The advertisement actually features women of all ages, and I suppose all shapes and sizes, participating in a variety of sports. It is of considerable encouragement to women in the community to know that it is possible for them to take up all sorts of sporting activities, particularly at the recreational level but certainly to levels of elite excellence, as we saw with our women in sport at those very Olympic Games.

That community service advertisement is very much part of the Government's program-in fact the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has set this as a target-to increase by three times the number of women involved in sport and listed as participants in recreational and sporting activities around the country. At the back of the report is an extensive list of the numbers of registrants in a variety of sports, and alongside those names is an allocation of money for those sports. The list makes most interesting reading.

The report also points out that there is need for further data, that we cannot take these figures as the final ones, but they are certainly the beginning of a very comprehensive coverage not only of women in sport but of all participants in sport-men and women, girls and boys-around this country. I think the Australian Sports Commission report indicates that we are beginning to collect that data. It is a very useful document.
