SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 symbolise the Government's success in running the economy of this country. That success depends greatly on the agreement which the Australian Labor Party reached with the unions in 1982-83 and which is known as the accord. The accord has undergone many an amendment and many a change, but the fundamental agreement that was reached has continued.

SPEECH.PARA: Unions have played an essential part in restoring this country to the state it is now in. Much criticism is often made, particularly by the Opposition, about the irresponsibility of unions, about their exercise of power. Indeed, the claim is made that unions have too much power and that they exercise that power wrongly. That theme is based on the proposition that the days of Mr Bounderby, which Dickens described in Hard Times, have passed-that employers, to a man, a woman and a company, are enlightened persons dedicated not only to making industry flourish but also to making workers rich. The argument goes that unions are all right in their place, but are usually more of a hindrance than of a help to their members, and that good work relations, good economics and good times require an emasculation of unions and of the union movement.

In that context I want to talk about two industrial matters which are presently going on in Victoria. These two matters are illustrations of just how little things have changed since Dickens's time and how great a need there still is for organised labour. The two disputes are one dealing with the meat workers and one dealing with theatrical and amusement employees. The one concerning the meat workers is at Portland. For many years now Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd has run a meat works at Portland which has provided work for hundreds of people, has provided income for the town, and has provided much of the prosperity of that region. Recently, Borthwicks was taken over by Australian Meat Holdings, which in turn has been purchased by Elders-IXL Ltd. Although the physical works are there and are still known as Borthwicks, the meat works are in fact run by Australian Meat Holdings, which in effect is Elders. For some months now the meat workers of Portland have been out of work for a variety of factors and have been on unemployment benefits. Elders has now purported to open the works to employees, but on conditions which Elders have set and which are quite below the conditions that operate in the rest of the meat works in Victoria and, as I understand it, in most of the works in Australia as a whole.

At one stage there was some suggestion that the Commonwealth Employment Service in Portland would see that the workers were not paid unemployment benefits while the conditions offered by Elders were available. As I understand it, that suggestion has been put very much to rest. The position is that yesterday the works at Portland were opened but only 10 people turned up to work at the works. There was a picket line consisting of 200 people. The picket line was conducted peacefully, in good order, and with considerable politeness to all those who approached it. Of course, nothing was done to the 10 people who crossed the picket line. Today 12 people crossed the picket line but the hundreds of people who are needed at the works did not attend.

Elders is a member of the Export Council of Victoria, which is a division of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Victoria. The Meat and Allied Trades Federation and the Export Council of Victoria have agreed to pay and conditions for meat workers which are satisfactory for those who want to work at Portland. In other words, if Elders, Australian Meat Holdings, were to meet the wages and conditions which have been agreed to by the Export Council of Victoria, by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, Portland meatworks could be operating, the town would have much more money coming into it and matters could proceed with a useful return to the meatworks, the workers and the town of Portland. But Elders refuses to accept wages and conditions that the Export Council, of which it is a member, and the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, of which it is also a member, have agreed to and it has unfortunately brought hardship-tragedy is not too strong a word-disputes and disorder to the Portland region.

Without the help and guidance of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, the Portland workers would be put in a situation in which they were paid less than and work under lesser conditions than the current conditions of other meat workers in Victoria. A smallgoods works, Castle Bacon Pty Ltd at Castlemaine, has workers who have agreed to work at wages and conditions less than those prevailing elsewhere, but with the exception of that smallgoods works, which is not a meatworks, every other member of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation in Victoria and the Export Council of Victoria is willing to provide, and in fact does provide, the wages and conditions available to workers in the rest of Victoria, which return profit for the meatworks which are properly run in Victoria.

This is a very poor state of affairs. It is a matter of great regret which ought to visit censure upon Elders, upon Australian Meat Holdings, that it should so conduct its industrial relations as to bring about the present quite disastrous situation. It is often said here that if an agreement is reached which benefits a works and employees in a particular industry the union should not interfere with that process. In this case, workers want to work at levels of wages and conditions which are given to their fellows in the rest of Victoria but a particular company refuses even to enter into negotiations with the union about them. The workers in this case want the union to negotiate with the company, yet Australian Meat Holdings, Elders, refuses to do so.

It is argued that people ought to be able to make agreements along the lines that they wish without interference from their union. The workers want the union to negotiate for them on wages and conditions with the employer, who is amongst those who trumpet and herald the need for new industry arrangements. The company should get down and negotiate with the union and, through the union, with the employees and return this works to operating on the profitable basis on which it has been operated in the past, which will enable the people of Portland, the meat workers of Portland and the region in general to profit and to flourish.

The second dispute relates to the cinema industry, which in Victoria is owned by three major chains-the Greater Union Organisation Pty Ltd, Village Roadshow Corporation Ltd and Hoyts Corporation Pty Ltd. Since 1981 they have operated under an agreement with the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association, which is the union which represents people working in the cinema industry in Australia. The union and the three chains have reached agreements over wages and conditions for some years. This year the agreement was up for renewal, which takes place every two years. Greater Union, Village and Hoyts came to an understanding which was then committed to writing and signed by Greater Union and Village, but Hoyts reneged on that agreement. Hoyts wanted lower staff ceilings and various conditions which the union and the people it represented would not agree to.

Since then, to jump ahead a bit, Hoyts has proposed working conditions for its employees, some of which I will list to illustrate the approach that Hoyts has taken in this matter. First, it wants to reduce the adult wage rate by about 45 per cent. That is worth repeating: this company wants to reduce by 45 per cent the rates that have been paid to its employees in the past. It wants to reduce by 45 per cent the wages which are presently being paid by the Greater Union and Village chains. It wants to introduce junior rates which are as low as 40 per cent of the reduced adult rate. The company wants to remove all security of employment from current awards and agreements. It proposes that no full-time staff need be employed. It wants to remove all overtime and award conditions for projectionists. It wants to introduce a 12-hour day with no penalties for Sundays, public holidays or night work. It wants to pay overtime only after 12 hours of work and then at time and a half. These are some of the conditions that it wants.

The dispute was taken to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission before a very experienced commissioner, Commissioner Mansini. On 9 September, Commissioner Mansini ordered that there be a return to the status quo. That meant that employees should return to employment and that Hoyts should provide to the workers who returned the pay and conditions which had operated prior to the dispute. The union agreed to that but Hoyts refused to obey the order of Commissioner Mansini, the order of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

There was a second hearing, on 15 September. Again Commissioner Mansini ordered a return to the status quo, again the union agreed and again Hoyts refused. The next day there was an application to Commissioner Mansini to clarify his directions. He clarified his directions. The union again agreed to abide by those directions. Again Hoyts refused. Hoyts then took proceedings to have Commissioner Mansini stand down from the case. That application having been made, Commissioner Mansini, quite understandably, stood down. But his order that there should be a return to the status quo continued to operate.

There was a further hearing in the Commission on 7 October before Mr Justice Williams who adjourned the matter to 10 October. On 10 October there was an application in the High Court by Hoyts by way of a prerogative writ of prohibition which sought to restrain Commissioner Mansini from further proceeding in the matter. Since then the matter has been in the hands of Mr Justice Williams. Hoyts refused to negotiate with the union. It refused to obey the order of Commissioner Mansini. It refused to pay the wages. It refused to provide the conditions that the other two chains have provided. In other words, it has introduced into the industry disorder, disputes and an attitude that did not formerly operate. It has disturbed a happy industrial climate. That, to say the least, is a great pity.

Those two disputes that now exist in Victoria illustrate the difficulty that unions find with some employers in achieving a good industrial relationship, in establishing a proper industrial climate and in introducing the sort of culture that should be introduced into the workplace in Victoria and, indeed, in Australia. The situation has been caused by two employers who have failed to show a proper social responsibility, who have failed to recognise that workers are more than automatons, that they are not robots-that they are human beings, who are entitled to reasonable wages and conditions, who are entitled to be heard in negotiations about what their wages and conditions ought to be and who are entitled to negotiate their wages and conditions through their unions for whose officers they can vote. It is a disturbing trend that organisations such as Australian Meat Holdings, Elders and Hoyts have such a lack of social and industrial conscience that they have brought these matters to their present situation.

I would like to discuss one other matter that is unrelated to industrial relations. One of the provisions made in the Appropriation Bills is for an amount of about $623m this year for law, order and public safety. Law, order and public safety are a fundamental function of government. All three arms of government-legislative, executive and judiciary-are concerned with it. The legislature makes the laws, the executive carries them out and the judiciary declares what they are.

Law, order and public safety cover a multitude of functions-courts, legal services, security and intelligence services, police, protective and custodial services. The rule of law is essential for the proper running of society. It can operate only if the community is dedicated to the great social values, including a hunger for justice, an appetite for compassion, and a dedication to altruism and integrity. Everybody is entitled to equality before the law, to due process in its application and to proper representation before its tribunals.

Equality before the law can be obtained only if there is adequate representation before tribunals. Legal aid is crucial to achieving this. Madam Acting Deputy President, your State and mine, Victoria, has a proud record in the provision of legal aid. The Legal Aid Commission, under Mr Julian Gardner, is an example. The Fitzroy Legal Service stands as a mighty symbol of what can be done.

The public has an interest in seeing that crime is prevented; that, if it is committed, it is detected; and that, when it is detected, it is punished. But the public also has an interest in a free, tolerant and benign society. Crime can be detected and perhaps prevented by oppressive instruments. In recent years there has been a growth in instruments to detect crime which move away from the traditional methods by which crime was formerly detected. The National Crimes Commission Act of 1982 was followed by the National Crime Authority Act of 1984, both of which changed traditional policing methods. For example, the Acts gave power to authorities to compel production of documents. It gave them power to examine witnesses under oath.

Those precedents have been followed in New South Wales by the setting up of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. The Act was passed this year and assented to on 6 July. In my view there is a danger that if commissions like this are set up and continue, in the end those sorts of methods of detecting or preventing crime become oppressive. Any democratic society, any free society, will have crime committed in it which, unfortunately, will go undetected and unpunished. The trouble is that if we try to ensure that every crime is detected, by no matter what method, we get close to having a police state. Under the Independent Commission Against Corruption Act, the Commissioner himself may issue a search warrant, if he thinks fit in the circumstances. He can compel the attendance of witnesses before him. He can examine them on oath and draw admissions from them. It is just a straw in the wind of what can happen.

There is a constant demand in Australia for more police powers. I have in front of me a dodger put out during the last Victorian election by the Police Association which calls for major changes in the instruments available to police in that State. It talks about the increased role of lawyers and the government's approach to these matters. It measures one party's promises against another. Of course, the police should be allowed to express their opinion. But if a police force starts to become politicised, if it starts to pick up one party rather than the other, its traditional policing role is very much endangered. It would be a great shame if the police force of Victoria, or indeed of any State, started to become politicised. Sir John Fortescue, a chief justice in the fifteenth century, said:
I should, indeed, prefer twenty guilty men to escape death through mercy, than one innocent to be condemned unjustly.
Sir William Blackstone in his Commentaries on the Laws of England said:
It is better that ten guilty persons escape than one innocent suffer.
One of the most outstanding judges in the Victorian Supreme Court, Mr Justice Crockett, said recently that it is better that 100 guilty people escape than one innocent suffer.

It is a fearful thing that innocent people should be punished. The most dramatic incident in Australia recently, of course, is the Chamberlain case, a most cruel and fearful occurrence which, let us hope, will not be repeated. But the attitude taken by some at the moment to the way the law ought to operate may well see such a case occur again. It is not only that people are punished but also that reputations can be ripped apart by innuendo. Indeed, in this chamber at times people's reputations are much damaged. If one looks at the way that reputations around Australia are pilloried at the moment, one observes that it is time we took stock of ourselves. I speak, for example, of the fearful tragedy in South Australia concerning Mr Sumner, the South Australian Attorney- General. I refer also to the way Mr Robin Gray in Tasmania has recently been attacked and, indeed, the way many members of the Cabinet in Queensland have had their reputations brought into public disrepute without having any real opportunity to defend themselves.

Procedures such as those taken by royal commissions can be very helpful. On the other hand, they contain a dark side which is that people's reputations through the reporting of the proceedings and the proceedings themselves can be much tarnished without any real opportunity of having them restored. I raise the issue at a time when we are relying on more extraordinary means of policing, where we have calls for royal commissions and where we have calls for judicial inquiries. In deciding whether to proceed with those things, we think of the potential they have not only for rooting out crime that should be rooted out in this community but also for destroying people's reputations and lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Chaney's proposed amendment in relation to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89. The position of Australian families is a matter of real concern to me and other members of the Liberal and National parties. Certain sections of the media would have us believe that the major parties, namely, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party, have been using the family as a political football. Certainly this Government has kicked families as readily as any football player kicks a ball around the field. Previous speakers have given a clear indication of just how this Government's policies have hurt families. There is no point in going on this afternoon to reiterate those arguments. We are all very familiar with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Those arguments, however, do not say that the family assistance scheme is of no assistance to families. That would be a ridiculous assertion to make. There is no attempt to ignore that initiative at all. But what we do say is this: firstly, that the need for the family assistance scheme, which is extra assistance for low income families, has been brought about by this insensitive Government's policies, and, secondly, that, irrespective of the family assistance scheme, middle income earners, those with too high an income to get that benefit, have been ignored by this Government.

When Senator Chaney accuses this insensitive Government of looking after only poor families he is quite right. Senator Crowley managed a contribution in this chamber a few days ago which I trust was not a little window into her intellectual ability. I am quite sure it was not. Senator Crowley took the complaint that the Government was only looking after poor families and the complaint that middle income families were being ignored and turned it, somehow, by some intellectual feat of gymnastics into a request to look after the rich.

Senator Crowley knows that was not the point being made. One wonders who, in fact, she thought would believe her. Senator Crowley went on to make much of her Government's impact on women entering the work force. She referred to the participation of women finally tipping the 50 per cent mark now. That is true of all women. It is equally true of married women if one chooses to limit the aspect at which one looks. Senator Crowley made much of Labor's claim to have created one million jobs since coming to office. She perhaps undersold Labor's achievement in that respect because I notice that the figures are something over one million.

I wish to spend a minute or two casting some light on what that bald figure alone does not tell the Senate. We may have been interested in the increase in the categories of jobs-that is, in terms of full time or part time jobs-broken down by sex. As it turns out, it will come as no surprise to honourable senators to hear that the biggest percentage increase in the categories of jobs by sex is that of married women taking part time jobs. It is true that, when one looks at the full picture in absolute terms, most of the jobs that have been created are full time jobs. I make no suggestion that that is not the case.

However, the biggest percentage increase is in women taking part time jobs. The increase is something like 36 per cent. Senator Crowley may well claim credit on behalf of the Government for this increase and extol the virtues of her Government's policies as they relate to women. To the extent that any policies of this Government improve the access of women to the work force, I am pleased. I am happy for barriers blocking women's entry to the work force to be broken down. But is that what this Government has done?

Is it not a more realistic perspective to look at this recent increase in women's part time work as being due to a variety of reasons? Perhaps the answer is yes. Some of the increase is perhaps a consequence of improvement of access. I refer in other words to a reduction in the barriers that currently limit women's access to the work force. It is also fair to accept an additional reason for the increase in women taking on part time work, namely, a rush of women into part time work because the standard of living of families has so fallen that with only one income earner those families who would otherwise choose to be single income families cannot afford to continue to make that choice. So economic reality takes the choice away from them and they are forced into the work force to do part time work. To the extent that this Government's policies have increased the number of women in the work force for that reason, it is to be condemned.

Another thing Senator Crowley did not mention in respect of the employment or unemployment market is the very large increase in duration of unemployment. Obviously all honourable senators would be pleased to see those who want jobs getting them; that is, to see a fall in the number of unemployed and, conversely, a rise in the number employed. But what about those people-albeit a smaller number-who are unemployed? The fact is that under this Government the duration of unemployment has extended quite dramatically. The younger people in this respect are not so badly off. When Labor came to office women under 18 had an average duration of unemployment of 22.7 weeks. Fortunately, by 1986 that period had gone up to only 23.3 weeks. But we find that for women from 45 to 54, at the older end of the labour force-women who obviously would have a greater difficulty in finding work-the figure has shifted from 63.7 weeks to 82.8 weeks. Taking an average of all age groups, the average duration of unemployment when this Government came to office was 42.7 weeks-no short period of time. In 1986 it had shifted up to 49.8 weeks. So in the labour force area there is some good news for women, married women in particular. But for those not lucky enough to have jobs the news is not good.

Senator Crowley's contribution also, in my view, purported to create the impression that this Government was responsible for the dramatic changes; that in fact something it had done had enabled more women to enter the work force than before. Senator Crowley sought to take some credit in that respect. As I have already said, some credit in that area may be due. But, of course, changes as dramatic as those that have occurred in status of women matters, particularly in respect of labour force participation, are not explained by a single stroke of the pen or a few words in anybody's speech. I would like to spend a few minutes briefly outlining some of those changes. Sometimes we get so used to change that we become accustomed to it and almost ignore it. It is useful to look back and take stock of what has happened. The number of females undertaking year 12 at school has increased by almost 66 per cent over the last 10 years. That is a phenomenal increase. The number of females undertaking university studies has increased by almost 40 per cent over the last decade.

Families are having fewer children. In 1972 the crude birth rate was 20 per 1,000. In 1987 it had fallen to 15. Families now tend to be smaller in terms of the number of dependent children. In 1969, 35 per cent of married couple families had three or more children. In 1985 only 27 per cent had three or more children. The average number of children per family has decreased from 2.09 in 1977 to 1.97 in 1985. The number of families with five or more children has decreased by 45 per cent between the years 1977 and 1985. Those few figures make quite clear the sort of changes families are undergoing in terms of the number of dependants that they have.

Dollar for dollar, family disposable income, which incidentally has fallen since 1984-85 under this Labor Government, has become, over a greater time span, greater than it has ever been. For example, in real terms it is now $385 a week. In 1966-1967 in real terms it was $298 a week. In terms of our disposable incomes we are wealthier; nonetheless we are having fewer children. Although the latest figures show the marriage rate today to be virtually the same as it was 25 years ago, the divorce rate is up. There has been an increase of 243 per cent from 1960 to 1987. We all know, of course, that there are now significantly more sole parents. In percentage terms the number of sole parent families has increased from 3.9 per cent of all families and non-family individuals in 1969 to 7.8 per cent in 1985.

These are quite startling changes. But to get back to the details with respect to the labour force to which Senator Crowley referred-namely, labour force participation of women and, in particular, married women-anybody who thinks that the streaming of women into the work force is a function of some gratuitous effort on the part of the Australian Labor Party should think again. I can provide some figures to indicate why I think my remark is justified. Married women have streamed into the work force. Let us, if we can, turn back to 1933. Those of us who cannot will have to rely on the records. In June 1933, when my mother was about 11, the labour force participation rate for married women was only 5 per cent. In 1954, two years after my mother had her fourth and last child-namely me-it was 12.6 per cent. A decade or more on, in 1968, when I was in year 11 at secondary school, the labour force participation rate of married women was 31.8 per cent. In 1978, when I got married, it was 41.9 per cent. This year it has reached 50.2 per cent.

Those figures indicate that from 1933 to now there has been a very steady progression of women into the work force, perhaps enhanced in some way by some policies that Labor has introduced and no doubt enhanced in some way by policies the Liberal Party of Australia has pursued. Of course it is a folly of parliamentarians to believe that it is what they do that has a significant impact on social attitudes. One might like to consider that in 1952, when I was born, the pill was not available. Some honourable senators may regret that having been the case. Nonetheless, at that time very few women went to university and the age of materialism was really just beginning to dawn. I can put that in some perspective by putting it this way: when I was at school the sign of mega-status was a set of Lakeland Derwent coloured pencils.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I remember.

—I am pleased to hear that the Minister remembers. If he was like me he would not have had a set. The status symbol has now changed; now the status symbol is a desktop personal computer with a graphics package and a colour monitor. Technology has produced more goods and a more effective way of saturating our brains with their availability.

SPEECH.PARA: The picture I have tried briefly to paint is one of enormous social change involving women, especially with respect to labour force participation-enormous social change that we now have to respond to. One of the responses we hear is, `Well, families must have more children'. We ask ourselves, `Why are families having fewer children?'. I suggest that the reason families are having fewer children is not simply a function of money. Anyone who is under the impression that by hurling money at families all of a sudden families will start to have more children should think again. I think the record shows that that is the case. Therefore, our fertility rate will not be altered simply by money. It is a question of changing social attitudes and values. Two-income couples with children do not love their children any less because both parents work. It is not my assessment that they have inferior values because they both work. They have simply made different choices from those which others have made. They may have made different choices for selfish reasons; at the same time, they may have made those choices because of what they want to give their children. They may have made the choice that they would rather have fewer children and give them a private education or overseas holidays. I would have thought that the classic Liberal philosophy is that families should make the choices that suit them. That is certainly my view.

I feel more sorry for two-income couples with children than I do for the `double income no kids' couples-the DINKS. They bear the acrimony of some single income families as a consequence of their having two incomes. What is forgotten is that both parents go to work; they both get on the bus every morning, go to work, and return home on the bus at night. In their spare time, in the evening hours or at the weekend, two-income families do their housework and help the kids with their homework. All of the housework is still done. Two-income families do not live in dirty hovels. They manage somehow, very largely by making a simple choice about how they want to live-whether they want to work to earn more, in order to give their children more, and whether, in order to do that, they are prepared to give up what would otherwise be leisure time and devote that time to housework.

Nonetheless, I admit that economic factors impact on choices. One would be silly to say that economic factors play no part in family choices; of course, they do. That is why I was careful to say that choices with respect to the number of children one has are not just a function of money, although money is certainly a part of it.

Accordingly, due to what some would describe as the dramatic fall in our fertility rate, a useful task for this Parliament would be to look at what we can do to assist families economically. We should look at whether the assistance we are providing at the moment is appropriate. If it is not, we should look at what we can do about it-whether we can redirect assistance or review assistance to help families at the time they need it most, which is when one parent in a two-income family leaves the work force to start a family. That is when they suffer a huge fall in family income, and that is when they certainly need the most help.

If one asks people aged about 40, 50 or 60 when they most needed assistance, inevitably they will say that it was when they started to have children. Perhaps the Government could look at allowing women, for example, to average their incomes. When a woman leaves the work force to start a family she should be able to accumulate income for, say, two or three years prior to leaving the work force. That income could be averaged over two or three years while she started a family. The income tax credits could either be simply paid back in cash or used as an income tax credit, should she choose to do part time work. As you and I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, many women who leave the full time work force to have children want to do some part time work. This does not mean that they do not like their children; they simply want to do some work as well as look after their children. The figure of 50.2 per cent of married women in the work force indicates that women are determined to do both. It is folly for anybody to think that he or she can turn back that tide.

We should be looking at ways in which we can assist people to make real choices about what they want to do. Under the scheme that I have proposed, if tax credits were stored for about three years after the woman had left the work force to have a child, she would be able to take some part time work without finding the child-care cost quite as prohibitive as many women now do.

We must develop policies, as I say, which allow families to make real choices. In that regard I believe the Liberal and National parties' industrial relations policy will make a real contribution to improving the choices that women have. It is my view that increased flexibility in the labour market will enable women to have greater access to that market. I believe they have been locked out of it. Unions and those who have jobs have kept the women out. I certainly recommend to Government members a quick, or perhaps not so quick, perusal of our industrial relations policy. Any elements of that policy that they can bring themselves to introduce prior to our taking government at the next election will be more than appreciated.

I will leave the comments that I chose to make with respect to family formation and what we can do about it and make a few brief comments on some remarks that have been made by certain Government senators with regard to my occasional refusal of leave to incorporate second reading speeches in Hansard over the last week or so. It is a normal courtesy which the Senate extends to a Minister, when introducing a Bill from the other place, to allow the second reading speech to be incorporated in Hansard. It is a sensible courtesy and it saves time. Generally speaking, there is no need to read the speeches in this place because they have already been read in the other place. Courtesies of the Parliament, however, have an element of mutuality about them. One extends them, and they are extended back. One withdraws them, and they are withdrawn from oneself. It is a fairly simple equation.

In the last sitting fortnight Senator Collins chose-incidentally, without letting me know-in a speech in the adjournment debate to make what some would describe as an attack on me. As Senator Collins obviously does not think it important to let people know when he is going to speak about them, I have not bothered to let him know that I am about to say something about him. The matter related to a press release of mine or, rather, some material attached to it. Senator Collins was of the view that I had broken the law. He came into the chamber full of moral outrage. As I suspect that most of us have broken the speed limit or something at some stage, I point out that his outrage was not at the law being broken but at the nature of the alleged breach as he saw it. The last words are reasonably important, because in giving legal opinions one thing is of paramount importance-that is, getting the facts right. If the facts are materially wrong, one's legal opinion is sure to be wrong. The next skill required is to understand the law as it stands. It is a skill that one expects of lawyers. One should be apprehensive about laymen taking this upon themselves. Senator Collins, if he is a layman, seems to have no such apprehension. He is quite confident of his ability-not a confidence shared by me or by any other person whose opinion I have sought on this matter.

I am not worried about what I see as ignorance or overconfidence on his behalf with respect to his legal ability. I am surprised that someone who served on the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, as Senator Collins did, would not take the opportunity that this presented to learn something of the law in this area. In Senator Collins's case this opportunity apparently was not taken up. I accept that my assessment is subjective; I may be wrong. The Government may care to prosecute me and test this matter. I think it unlikely that it will do that, so we will never really know. I remain confident that my assessment of the law is correct and that I have not broken the law.

I am concerned about the facts, with respect to Senator Collins's allegation, being wrong. With regard to incorrect information, we understand that there is often a measure of ignorance, stupidity, incompetence or, sadly, on some occasions, bad faith. If one is ignorant of the facts of a matter and does nothing, it matters little, because one can wallow in one's ignorance. But if one wants to pick up that ignorance and attack someone with the consequences of it-namely, incorrect statements-in my view, one is stupid, incompetent or acting in bad faith. I had not previously thought of Senator Collins as stupid, although I am not sure whether I think of him in that way now. I had not thought of him as being the essence of incompetence. I do not think of him in that way now, either.

Senator Collins, on the occasion to which I referred, treated the Senate to a long commentary on his Sunday mornings in the Northern Territory spent watching, for example, the Reverend Jimmy Swaggart on television. He suggested that that gentleman, while posing as an upholder of moral values, was in fact a fraud, a degenerate and a crook. The object of this exercise was not clear to me. Its relevance seemed doubtful. I can only assume that Senator Collins was implying that people who vocally uphold moral values, or what they see as being of moral value, are deep down prone to be crooks and frauds. I had not thought of Senator Collins as being weak, but I wonder why we were treated to his view if it was not to make such an imputation, namely, that those who do that are in some way crooks and frauds. One wonders why, if that is what he thought, he did not come straight out and say it.

I am surprised that an honourable senator would come into this place and verbally paint an incorrect picture without checking the facts. As my alleged actions formed the subject of his allegations, one might have thought he would bother to check them with me. Some honourable senators may think his not having done so says quite a lot about his competence as a senator. That he neither made such inquiries nor let me know of this proposed attack certainly says something about the courtesies that he is prepared to extend.

As to the question of competence, I wish to add one further remark. One of the first things one is taught in legal practice or articles as they relate to court work or advocacy is: if one does not think one is going to like the answer to a question, one should not ask it. Perhaps Senator Collins, being an advocate for himself in this matter-being an advocate, as I understand it, of this sort of offensive trash and rubbish being available all over Australia through the Australian Capital Territory-decided just that: not to ask me a question that he may not like the answer to. In a sense, he may have deliberately decided to remain in ignorance, to avoid a question he did not think he would like the answer to.

The second thing one is taught is that if one is unsure of what the answer might be, and especially if one suspects one might not like the answer, one should not, for heaven's sake, base anything on the answer, because that is an incompetent risk. Senator Collins took that risk and made allegations on the basis of the facts as he would like them to be. He had an opportunity to check them out and he failed to take the opportunity. He took a chance that they would be right. He came into this chamber and attacked another senator on that basis. It was bad odds. The matters as he presented them are incorrect. Senator Collins has been misled, or has misled himself, and consequently has misled a lot of others, including colleagues and the media.

Certain sections of the media were misled by what was said in here, and perhaps Senator Collins spoke to some of them directly, outside this chamber. I wonder whether Senator Collins would feel any responsibility if, as a consequence of his remarks, I had chosen to sue, and had successfully sued, certain sections of the media. I take deep offence at the suggestion that I am the sort of person who distributes pornography willy-nilly around Parliament House, especially in a manner that enhances its availability to small children.

Would Senator Collins say that he was not responsible, or would he say that the media should have checked with him or that they misunderstood him? Why is there a tighter standard for them than for him? He did not check his facts with me, so why should they check theirs with him? Is it because they risk libel and slander? Surely their duty in this regard is matched by his: to get the facts right before setting himself up as judge and jury. Does he not think they ought to be able to rely on what he says? If not, is he not thereby admitting his own unreliability?

I have made some inquiries following Senator Collins's remarks as to the availability of this material. It was widely distributed around Parliament House but, as my interjection recorded in Hansard indicated, not by me. Certain sections of the media have their views as to who is responsible. Senator Collins seems to have held himself out as an expert as to its availability. I wonder how he knew the extent of its distribution. He knew more than I did. Perhaps he could cast light on who really was responsible for its willy-nilly distribution around Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Labor Government came to power it claimed that the economy was in tatters. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), supposedly claimed to be the world's best, has boasted that he has restored Australia's economic sovereignty. Indeed, his opening words in this year's Budget Speech are very well worth noting. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . tonight I can report to the people of Australia that the nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation . . .
It is a Budget that will do much to secure our future.
It is a Budget which consolidates the progress since 1983, and locks onto our targets, the balance of payments deficit and inflation.

. . . this Budget is the right Budget at this time, and provides Australia with a unique set of outcomes and priorities which could only be delivered by the heart, creativity and intellectual strength of the Australian Labor movement.

The rhetoric is there but it is very sadly lacking in reality. The reality is that since that speech in August the key economic factors, which the Treasurer himself classed as significant, are way off the Government's estimates. For the past five years the Treasurer's predictions and promises on inflation have not once been met. Each year, with the exception of his first Budget, inflation has been higher than predicted. There is no doubt that he will once again be wrong this year because the predicted 4.5 per cent inflation rate seems almost impossible, even after only four months of the new financial year.

This Budget depends on two significant factors: the balance of payments and inflation. Mr Keating was confident in August that he could keep Bill Kelty and the unions off the boil to hold down inflation and that he had divine intuition that commodity prices would increase export earnings and therefore improve the balance of payments position. The reality now is that Australia's trade deficit has been blown right off course, and with it has gone the linchpin of the whole of the Budget strategy.

Contrary to the Treasurer's claims, Australia's economy is deteriorating, not improving. Our current account deficit is already $685m worse than for the same period last year. The balance of payments deficit figure for October was $1.685 billion, with imports up by 18 per cent, and the balance on merchandise trade at a record deficit figure of $681m. We have no hope of coming in under the projected $9.5 billion, and there is a real risk that our current account deficit will increase by $2 billion to $3 billion. In recent days interest rates have risen. I know that well, being in the farming community, because we have to have overdrafts and the interest rate on overdrafts has gone up quite substantially. In fact, it is now about 18 per cent. The value of the Australian dollar has also risen, so that is also affecting our commodity prices on such items as wool and wheat, which have fallen quite dramatically in a short period.

The unions are restless and the Treasurer cannot be as certain as he was a few months ago that he has the Australian Council of Trade Unions under control. He has only another few months to go before he will have quite heavy pressures put on him. The losers as a result of his failure to read the economy correctly will not only be the Government but also the home buyers, who will be unable to pay the 15 per cent-plus interest rate which is now the going rate for home loans. Small business will also be the loser, as it depends on loan finance. The losers will also be the farmers, who depend on strong export commodity prices, which I have already mentioned. The losers will also be, and already are, the State governments, which are faced with increasing costs for roads, education and health. Even today the national account figures have analysed gross domestic product (GDP) growth over the last three months at 0.3 per cent. Senator Stone asked a very good question on this matter in the Senate this afternoon. I can-not say that the answer was as good as the question. I think Senator Walsh had quite a deal of trouble in answering the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was too long.

—The question was not too long. It was a very good and detailed question, a question which was put with a lot of thought and application. I am afraid the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) was found well and truly wanting in his answer to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Economists are already expressing concern at this figure and at where the economy is going. Again, the Treasurer's prediction of an annual growth figure of 12 per cent appears unable to be met. We have heard the same rhetoric from this Treasurer for two years about where the current account is heading. In March 1986 he said that he remained confident that:
a downward trend in the current account deficit would emerge during that year.

We are still to witness this downward trend some 31 months later. Obviously, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is in the chamber, would be very concerned about this because every Australian is worried about the fact that we are living beyond our means. There is a concern not only to the Minister on her salary but also to all people in the community. It means that the standard of living for the ordinary, average Australian is continuing to decline. Australians know that it does not matter how hard they work-they can work as hard as they like-they will really not get any further ahead. Taxes and inflation are continuing to eat away at the very heart of the good Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't they do something?

—That is a good question. Why does the Government not do something about it? It is high time it did. Every time young people get close to a deposit for a house or land the price soars. Every time they work out their household budget to see whether they can afford the repayments, the interest rate goes up. This is reflected in the number of homeless people and families living below the poverty line. While we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) making pledges about children not living in poverty, another family gets taken into care or evicted from a house it can no longer afford to rent. More than 700,000 Australians have now fallen below the poverty line since this Government came to power. More than 60,000 people live on the verge of homelessness; 40,000 people sleep in refuges by night and are forced to roam the streets by day.

SPEECH.PARA: This is from a government that claims it is compassionate to the poor and needy in our society. SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to use the short time available to me to canvass the expenditure of the Government; rather I want to look at something that is relatively rarely dealt with in this chamber-that is, how information relating to the expenditure of money is given to the Parliament. It is very important, in fact it is crucial, that the Parliament be fully informed. The Government is responsible and accountable for all the expenditures that are made, for it is money that is taken from the community, not government money, that is spent annually. The senators in this chamber have a special right to know how that money is being spent because they are the elected representatives of the community, and to some degree we all bear a responsibility for the accountability of the expenditure. One of the great prerogatives of government is that it can raise whatever money it wants in the form of taxes and other charges. It is government's equal prerogative to spend that money in any way it sees fit. If the community does not like what the Government is doing with respect to raising and spending money the recourse is through the ballot box at the next election.

But the other side of the coin, balancing the privilege of raising money and spending it, is accountability. There is an absolutely inescapable obligation on the Government to account for every penny it spends. The Federal Government, whatever its political orientation, does that. An elaborate system of checks and balances is built into the federal system to make it so. We, as individual senators, have a part in it whether we are in government or in opposition.

I contrast this with the actions of the Government in my State of Queensland, where the community has no assurance of accountability of the expenditure of funds other than the word of the Premier of the day. The Queensland State Parliament has no way of exploring the expenditure made by executive government, the Ministry or the departments of state beyond the limits which are permitted by the executive government of the day. That does not apply in this chamber and in the Federal Parliament.

I re-emphasise the central point that, in return for the right to impose and collect taxes for the betterment of society as a whole, a government has an inalienable obligation to account for the expenditure of those taxes. In the Federal Parliament there are a number of ways in which this comes about. There are extensive Budget papers; there are the Appropriation Bills; there is the Joint Committee of Public Accounts; and there are Senate Estimates committees. The Senate Estimates committees cover every department of the Federal Government and examine the proposed expenditure for the year. Representatives of each department are required to appear before the relevant committees to answer questions put by senators about expenditure. Departmental officers are obliged to answer fully and accurately any questions relating to proposed or past expenditure, but they are not required to explain the reasons for that expenditure. That is the responsibility of the government of the day. The government of the day decides where the money is spent and it is for that government to justify that spending to the electorate. But it is for the public servants to account for the amounts that are spent and accurately reveal them to the Parliament.

It is necessary to have Estimates committees because it is simply impossible in one single document to cover the expenditure of the annual Budget of the Federal Parliament, which is now in excess of $70 billion a year. The limitations on Senate Estimates committees are the knowledge of the individual senators about the particular departments and their competence at questioning the public servants. Another limitation can be the degree of cooperation of the public servants with the Parliament.

Having now completed my eleventh year as a member of an Estimates committee for the main annual Estimates, I have no hesitation in saying that the quality of evidence given to committees varies considerably from department to department. Some departments are open and friendly; many others require some degree of persistence and determination, to put it euphemistically, to elicit the desired information. While it is desirable, of course, that information be freely given, it is an absolute requirement that information be accurate and not misleading.

Without going deeply into the matter, I want to talk about the politicisation of the senior levels of the Australian Defence Force. I have referred to this matter in the past in this chamber. The only point I want to add is that I emphasise that I am not talking about the politicisation in party political terms. That is not part of my argument at all. When witnesses appear before Senate Estimates committees they are appearing before the Parliament and the people of Australia because they, as public servants, are accounting to the people of Australia for the expenditure of public moneys. The central point of my speech this afternoon concerns the evidence of one witness during the estimates for the Department of Defence this year which, in the most favourable light, is grossly and wilfully misleading and, at worst, is dishonest. Some brief background material is required before going into details. The Australian Department of Defence has been engaged for at least a decade in developing a new secure communications network. The system consists of three blocks. The first block is called Project Raven, which deals with the design and production of a whole family of mobile radio sets and message gear for use in the field. The second block is Project Parakeet, which is the next step in the communications equipment chain, again for use in the field. Finally there is Project Discon, which is a fixed secure communications system around the country between defence headquarters and establishments-almost like a private Telecom network for the Services, with the exception that it is secure against eavesdropping and interdiction.

The first project, Project Raven, is proceeding reasonably satisfactorily. Apart from the fact that Project Discon seems to be moving at a very slow pace, almost at glacial pace, it seems to be coming along satisfactorily, but Project Parakeet is not going well.
