Six months after we had an assurance that there was no delay on the program contemplated we are told categorically that there is at least a 12-month delay coming. We were given no indication in April that the management and technical side of the program was not proceeding satisfactorily, yet Major-General Francis in evidence affirmed that there were major management and technical problems with the company as well as financial ones in so far as it was not meeting the contract. In other words, all the reports that were in the press in the early part of this year have been confirmed in the latter part of the year, in the face of contradictions from a witness from the Department of Defence.

Everyone who had an interest in this field knew that the prime contractor, Racal, was experiencing significant managerial problems within its own company and that those problems were flowing on to the way it was managing this very large program. Everyone knew that there were very considerable technical problems in the development of the equipment, not the least with the Scandinavian subcontractor who was developing the switchgear and simply could not deliver. In Department of Defence contracts of this nature, once a prime contractor has been selected and his performance is satisfactory, although the stages are let sequentially, the prime contractor will almost always be granted the successive phase because his performance has been acceptable to the Department in the early ones. Everyone knew that, although it was a five-phase contract, at the end of phase 3 it would go to open tender because the Department was not satisfied. That information was withheld from the Committee by the witness. The Senate has certain rules as to the conduct of witnesses. Only this year, on Wednesday, 24 February 1988, on the matter of parliamentary privilege, resolutions covering the appearance of witnesses were passed by this chamber. Resolution (12) deals with offences by witnesses, et cetera. It reads:
(12) A witness before the Senate or a committee shall not:
(a) without reasonable excuse, refuse to make an oath or affirmation or give some similar undertaking to tell the truth when required to do so;
(b) without reasonable excuse, refuse to answer any relevant question put to the witness when required to do so; or-
this is the relevant one in the case of Dr McIntosh-
(c) give any evidence which the witness knows to be false or misleading in a material particular,
or which the witness does not believe on reasonable grounds to be true or substantially true in every material particular.

There is a charge to be laid against the good doctor that he has misled the Senate on a very important point. In April, when asked whether Project Parakeet was behind schedule, Dr McIntosh responded `Not significantly, no'. When it was put that there were serious technical problems with the project the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who was at the table, stated that Dr McIntosh had already said that there were no significant problems. This characterisation of Dr McIntosh's answers was accepted by the Committee. As the transcript shows, I gave Dr McIntosh the opportunity to resile from his previous assurances that there were no problems with this program because I knew very well there were highly significant problems. I gave him that chance, as the Hansard shows. I asked:
I put it to you there are serious technical problems with Parakeet. Is that true or false?
I cannot put it more clearly than that: `Is is true or false?' Senator Richardson responded:

Dr McIntosh has now answered the question three times. I wonder how many times he is expected to answer it. He has said that there are no significant problems. He has said it a couple of times now. I think that is probably enough.
I gave Dr McIntosh his chance. I said:
So long as Dr McIntosh realises that that is the position on the record.
There was not a word from Dr McIntosh. Senator Richardson intervened:
I am sure that he recognises that it is on the record. He has had to repeat it several times. He seems happy to live with it.

That was the position. Dr McIntosh did not resile from the answers he gave to the Senate. When I asked whether the date for the equipment being in operation had been set back as a result of technical difficulties, Dr McIntosh replied, `At this time, no'. Yet in the Estimates Committee six months later Major-General Francis stated that it was expected there would be overall about a year's delay on Parakeet. It is not only the delay that is the critical point here; there is the matter of the technical performance of the company, the management and the cost. All of those things were withheld from the Parliament.

Dr McIntosh is a very senior officer. He above anyone else in this country was in a position, and is in a position, to know the status of Project Parakeet not only now but at the start of the year and certainly at April. He knew what the true story was. He knew through the press accounts that were being published at the time, which subsequent events have proved to be accurate in their reporting. He went to the Committee and he misled it as to the true status of a very expensive program which is crucial for the communications of the Australian defence forces. I do not believe he is stupid. This was a premeditated attempt to mislead the Parliament.

I have not yet decided whether I will refer this matter to the Privileges Committee for an opinion but I want to use this opportunity to say to any witnesses in any department-and it is not a personal view-that the Senate will have no hesitation in applying the full weight of its powers to discipline those who transgress the basic principles outlined in the resolution of the Senate. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have ferreted Government senators out of their offices and the billiard rooms of Parliament House they would do very well to stay in this chamber to listen to what I have to say. I wish to address the question of homeless youth in society. Many Labor electorates have this problem starkly in the streets. Homeless youth, or street kids as they are commonly known, are a serious social and economic problem for Australia. The issue was the subject of a Senate inquiry in 1982. The only member of that inquiry still a member of the Parliament is Senator Shirley Walters from Tasmania. She has been at the forefront in bringing this issue to the Parliament. I know she wishes no congratulations or thanks on this matter for her compassionate stance; all she really cares about is that someone from the Government side should do something about the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take up the banner of this issue and bring it to the attention of the Parliament. I believe it is very much a symptom of modern Australia: Australia has not had such a problem in the past. Owing to good luck Australia has been relatively free of extreme poverty and ghetto living. We can no longer claim that that is the case. When the figure for homeless youth is 30,000, that is extreme poverty and ghetto living. Homeless youth range from the age of 10 to 18 years. But the age category can be broadened to 10 years to 25 years. Whilst homeless youth are not a homogenous group they share some common factors. They have been rejected by their families, either abused or victimised at home and are mostly economically and socially disadvantaged. Therein lies the problem. The common factor is their home life. A high percentage of homeless youth come from broken families and families undergoing crises.

The Senate should reflect not only on the profile of our homeless youth but also on what that means to our society. These young people have no permanent shelter. Their shelter is either basic or they have none. The streets, the rubbish bins and the parks are where they sleep. They have no permanent employment. It is safe to say that they have no employment at all. To make money to be able to live, the worst cases will either thieve or turn to prostitution. As the Senate would be aware, turning to prostitution inevitably results in the use of drugs. The use of drugs inevitably results in drug peddling. So life becomes a downhill slide. In this state, they become exploited by adults in the pornography and drug underworld. The exploiters of these youth I would declare to be some of the most vile of our criminals. This problem in our society is compounding. It is a problem for all of us, as it affects all of us.

The basic need of these youth is shelter. Shelter supplies them with a basic emotional and physical security. This security can be supplied through our Government's social welfare system, either by providing funds directly to the refuges, or by direct payments to youth through youth assistance schemes. Whatever scheme is implemented, it is necessary that all levels of government become involved in the welfare of this lost generation of Australians in a coordinated fashion, dedicated to relieving the plight of these homeless youth. This is a fundamental responsibility of all governments, not just for compassion's sake-compassion is easily felt-but also for the long term well-being and stability of our society. A proportion of the budget at every level of government must go towards solving this problem. I cannot imagine any Australian objecting to the use of government funds in this way.

The Government's support is most notable in a joint scheme between the Commonwealth and States, known as the supported accommodation assistance program, which incorporates not only the Federal Government and State governments but also local government and the numerous voluntary agencies. It provides funds for crisis accommodation and related support services for homeless people. Under the supported accommodation assistance program there is a subprogram directly tailored to homeless youth-the youth supported accommodation program.

Without doubt, these programs are necessary to help homeless youth, but even if the Government were to double its contributions it would not be getting to the substance of the problem or minimising it. It is recognised that many factors lead to homelessness. Indeed, I have outlined some of these factors already. Undoubtedly, the breakdown of the family unit perpetuated by the Family Law Act has been one of the major factors. However, another major factor, the new economic forces over the past six years, is what I particularly wish to concentrate on. Crucial to understanding the explosion of homelessness in society is the general downturn in the Australian economy over the past six years.

It surely must be recognised that Australia's economy has declined over the past six years. Its standard of living has declined. Australia has carried massive trade deficits over the past six years. Last month we faced a staggering figure of $1.7 billion. Australia is carrying a foreign debt of $115 billion, a growth from $32 billion in the past six years. Further to this, Australia has endured widely fluctuating interest rates and inflation rates. Short term interest rates in the past six years have reached as high as 20 per cent. Housing interest rates have reached 15 per cent. The inflation rate, whilst it sits at 7.5 per cent today, has reached the 10 per cent mark in the past six years. The value of the Australian dollar has also fluctuated over the past six years, falling from $1 per US dollar to 64c, rising to its level today of 87c Australian.

In volatile, troubled and uncertain economic times, it is always those on the bottom rung who are hit the hardest economically. Volatility is one of the most damaging factors for these people. All the prime indicators I have mentioned reflect upon the value of money. Those who are greatly disadvantaged in society lose more in proportion by a decrease in the value of money. There is little doubt that the greater the economic pressures placed upon a family, the greater the problem of homelessness will be. This is because of the tension that is brought into the home by economic failure. It is incumbent upon all governments to work toward establishing the fundamentals of the economy so as to support the family unit that, in turn, supports each individual within the family.

What, then, is happening to the family at the micro level? The family allowance is a miserable $7 per week per child. It has been that figure from day one of this Government. The dependent spouse rebate is a miserable $830 per year. That figure has also remained static. In 1983 the dependent spouse rebate for families with children was $963. In 1984, I concede that it went up to $1,030. But that is where it has been locked in. Over the past six years the family allowance has decreased in real terms by 32 per cent, the dependent spouse rebate by 32 per cent and the dependent spouse rebate for families with children by 27 per cent. The Government's attempt to target the poorer families by introducing the family allowance supplement has been a failure. The take-up rate of this allowance has been very low. It is little wonder. The introduction of an assets test upon the allowance supplement payment immediately eliminates most, if not all, poorer family farmers. Clearly, the cut-off figure of $300,000 for the capital value of the farm is too low. It is utterly unrealistic and destroys the hopes of so many family farmers who wish to raise their families in some security and with some peace of mind.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated over the weekend that he intended to increase the family allowance supplement by a miserly $2. That is too little, too late. The family allowances and rebate payments are inadequate, cloaked as they are in this Government's tax system. The bulk of pay as you earn taxpayers are family men and women. The tax system over the past six years has seen over two million Australians pushed into the high tax bracket of 40c in the dollar. It is estimated that another one million Australians will enter those high tax brackets in the coming year.

Since 1983 tax on average weekly earning has increased by over 56 per cent. These staggering figures have had a very destructive effect upon the Australian family's standard of living. The neglect of the family in this way has been compared by Carl Anderson to the callous days of the Industrial Revolution. I quote from Carl Anderson's speech at the International Congress on the Family, which was held in Paris recently, because it is pertinent to the subject I address today. He said:
Contemporary Government neglect of the family bears a striking similarity to the mid-nineteenth century capitalist's view of men, women and children as autonomous members of the work force.
That is the crux of the argument I am trying to get through to the Government. Men, women and children are not autonomous members of the work force.

This brings us to the issue of the Government's child care policy. The Government's policy of subsidising particular child-care centres favours the better off in society and the double income families, over and above the single income families. Why should a mother who chooses to stay at home to care for the family be financially penalised? That analysis is backed up by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has condemned this Government's own child-care policy. The only equitable and efficient alternative to the Government's current policy is additional child-care support for all mothers, either by way of direct payment or tax deduction per child.

The combined effect of the Government's ill-directed child-care policy and the decline in the Government's family assistance measures, along with the overall decline in the economy over the past six years, has deepened the unemployment crisis of the young in Australia. For many young people homelessness and unemployment go hand in hand. It is a vicious cycle. To state the obvious, unemployment precludes many of these young people from affordable housing. Homelessness prevents young people from building a solid environment from which to obtain and remain in employment.

The high level of youth unemployment is, of course, closely linked to the poor performance of the economy and to the consequent declining level of family income which has forced many mothers into the paid work force. Low income families are the first to be confronted with this financial decision that both parents should work. It should be clear-it is what I believe-that most women would prefer to stay at home to raise a family but are forced to work due to the economic plight their family has been placed in. Sadly, this has squeezed many young school leavers out of the employment market.

An array of examples can be given to show how the social welfare system, the tax system and the economic system of this Government are skewed against the traditional family unit. These economic effects upon the family unit constitute one of the major factors perpetuating the plight of homeless youth in our society. Their plight is one of the greatest social and economic challenges before Australia, particularly in a time when Australia is laying its economic foundations for the year 2000. Indeed, if genuine help is not given to these street kids we may not only be facing a devastating and depressing economic future but we will also be facing a very troubled and uneasy social future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the appropriation debate in the Senate today to speak about the allocations received by my State under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act of 1986. May I say from the outset that I am very pleased that the only Minister we have from Tasmania is in the chamber today.
—And a shadow one.

—I thank the shadow Minister. Honourable senators present may be interested to know that since 1976, when this country was under the commendable leadership of Malcolm Fraser, there has been a system in operation whereby the States have allocated Commonwealth grants to local bodies on the recommendation of the State grants commissions. It was during the final year of operation of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1985-86 that an amendment to that Act brought in indexation. That amendment limited the total allocation in that year to $535m, which was 2 per cent in real terms over what had been allocated the year before. This amendment broke, for the first time, the relationship between personal income tax receipts and the amount which was allocated to local government. That system formed part of the relationship between Federal and local governments for some nine years. I think it is fair to say that it was a relationship which was mutually beneficial to both parties and which provided a clear guide to local governments as to the funds they were due to receive.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986-87, following the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance headed by Professor Peter Self, the Commonwealth Government in its wisdom chose to quash the legislation which had been in operation since 1976. It introduced revised arrangements under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act. The allocation for the first two years of that Act was based on the previously allocated 1985-86 amount indexed against the consumer price index (CPI).

The breaking of the link between personal income tax receipts and the amount allocated to local government served to disadvantage local government. Those receipts increased at a greater rate than the CPI. As part of the new legislation State grants commissions were also required-perhaps a better word is forced-to formulate a new principle for approval by the Commonwealth Minister. The new principles under which the State grants commissions had to operate were based largely on guidelines which Commonwealth officers had prepared. As a result, State grants commissions were forced to alter fundamentally the way they allocated their grants from 1987 onwards.

In my own State, the Tasmanian Grants Commission was no exception, with the Commission being required to make a number of important changes and modifications to the way it operated. Sensing that this would cause both the councils and the Grants Commission some concern, it was decided to phase in these new procedures over a three-year period. In Tasmania the 1987-88 allocation for the Commission was based on 80 per cent of the old system and 20 per cent of the new. For the year 1988-89 it will be 60 per cent and 40 per cent.

The change to a population basis by the Federal Government was finally achieved in the current financial year. The most significant disadvantage of this change was obviously incurred by Tasmania, although Western Australia and New South Wales also suffered to some extent. For 1988-89 the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act stipulates that the total amount of financial assistance to local government is to be arrived at by altering the amount for 1987-88 by the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose grants to the States. Because of changes to the funding of hospital services agreed to in May 1988 at the Premiers Conference, there was a need to identify health grants. As a result, the Commonwealth has now amended the grant determination procedure.

The outcome of these changes is that local government in Australia will be provided this year with a fixed amount of $652.5m. This represents a notional increase of $15.8m, or 2.5 per cent. The reality is that local government will be faced with a decrease of $22.4m, or 3.3 per cent, in comparison to what it received in 1987-88.

We have heard much, particularly from the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), about this Government's so-called commitment to local government. We heard a lot about that during the referendum debate. I challenge the Government to put its record in relation to local government up for public scrutiny because I sincerely believe that this Government is attempting to dupe local government by upholding itself as the benevolent provider on the one hand, but in reality doing very little. It is very easy to understand when one has contact with Senator Reynolds. She is a very charming lady. I am the first to admit that she has done a very good job of charming local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —She didn't win the referendum though, did she?

—At least now we notice that local governments are starting to show their concern. My colleague from Tasmania quite rightly points out that the Minister may have charmed local government on the surface, but the people of Australian were not charmed during the referendum debate. A quick comparison of the level of Commonwealth funding to local government over the period 1976 to 1988 on the basis of a percentage of the previous personal income tax share arrangements reveals that funding peaked between 1980 and 1983 under Malcolm Fraser, when the level steadied at 2 per cent. Under Mr Hawke, in 1988-89 we see the funding level reduced to a pitiful 1.66 per cent. Tasmania's share of the total amount has been declining in recent years. As I have mentioned, under the provisions of the new Act, for example, in 1986-87 Tasmania received 3.17 per cent of the total pool, whereas for this year, 1988-89, the figure will fall to 2.8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The future looks even less favourable for local government in Tasmania. For ongoing years we will see local government receive a share based on population alone. All local governments in Tasmania are therefore facing real problems because of their declining share of Commonwealth assistance. It has been estimated that during 1988-89 Tasmania will receive $18.53m. This will be a reduction of around $603,000, or 3.2 per cent, and a real terms reduction of $1.75m, or 8.6 per cent. These figures indicate quite clearly that the position for Tasmania is particularly difficult, as the cutbacks imposed on local government in Tasmania have been 2 1/2 times as bad as those imposed on an Australia-wide basis.

An interesting point which has emerged from a recent conference of all State grants commissions is that the South Australian Grants Commission gave notice that South Australia's State Treasury had recently raised with Mr Hawke the possibility of the Commonwealth undertaking a major review of the distribution of funds between the States. It is apparent that people within local government are not happy with these revised arrangements and, despite the protestations of the Government, they are proving to be far from equitable. In my capacity as secretary of the coalition's local government committee, I am continually receiving representations from local government all over Australia. Very serious problems have been brought to us by the Local Government Association of New South Wales. This week the Municipal Association of Victoria is waiting upon us, and I am pleased to say that we will be meeting with that association tomorrow. These groups all have the same concerns-not only in regard to their declining funding rates in general grants to the States but also in respect of road funding.

I believe the State grants commissions are saying that if they themselves are being forced to distribute funds amongst the councils on an equalisation rather than on a per capita basis, surely the same principles must apply to the Commonwealth in its distribution of funds to the States. The Federal Government wants to deal with this matter in whatever way best suits its own objectives. It forces councils to distribute funds on an equalisation basis but refuses to acknowledge the same principles in its own distribution of funds amongst the States. Personally, I believe that Tasmania would fare much better under such a system than the 2.84 per cent which is currently being received under the per capita based distribution. I strongly urge that this Government examine the funding relativities which exist between the States. What is being sought here is really not unreasonable. It would bring the distribution of funds for local government into line with the methods used for the distribution of general revenue assistance amongst the various States and the Northern Territory and would therefore provide a more even outcome for all concerned.

Local government continues to suffer under Mr Hawke. It has seen itself slowly shrinking away as a part of total public sector activities. Indeed, over the past two decades local government's share of taxes collected by all governments has dropped from 5.6 per cent to a measly 3.7 per cent as the Federal Government has increased its massive tax grab. The Federal Government's measures have hurt local government in Tasmania, and they will certainly continue to do so. I note with interest a press release from the office of Senator Reynolds herself, dated 22 August 1988. It states:
Tasmania's share of financial assistance grants in 1988-89 decreased by 3.2% compared to an increase of 2.2% in 1987-88 and the national average increase this year of 2.5%.

So even the Minister for Local Government has agreed that Tasmania's share of financial assistance grants has decreased quite significantly. I think this is worth repeating because we can see that, while national funds have increased by 2.5 per cent, Tasmania's share has decreased by 3.2 per cent. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is from Tasmania, to take note of those figures. I am sure he must have been made aware of those figures by local government in Tasmania. I hope that he passes those concerns on to the Minister.

The implications of these measures are that only nine out of 46 Tasmanian councils have received even the slightest increase in their funds, while only one council will receive more in the next year than it did in real terms in 1987-88. That is an indictment of this Government's policy of reducing assistance to local government in Tasmania and in fact all over Australia. It is very easy to pass the buck to local governments, because they are the ones at the end of the line. We all know that it is politically expedient to get local government to increase its rates and make itself unpopular with the people. The Federal Government does not get the political flak and the blame for the effect of these measures on the family budget when the rate demands fall due. As I said before, it is local government that is at the end of the queue and that cops all the flak from the unfortunate decisions that are being made at a Federal level.

In support of that suggestion I quote from the Burnie Advocate of Wednesday, 24 August. It is headed `Councils cheesed off by Federal grants cuts'. I know that very good cheese is made at Lactos in Burnie, but the councils certainly were not cheesed off in that way. According to the article, the Warden of the Waratah Council said that `some of the smaller jobs the council had planned would no longer go ahead'; at Penguin the Warden, E. Dyke, `described the cuts as ``very serious'' '; the Warden of Wynyard, Councillor Chalk, said `the cuts . . . would affect the municipality and make things difficult'; and Latrobe's Warden, Councillor Ford, said that `the $2065 cut had been expected and the council's budget had taken the cut into consideration'. But he said also that `one of the reasons rates continued to rise was to cover the decreases in Commonwealth funding'. We now move down the west coast to Strahan. We all know that Strahan is one of the smallest municipalities in Tasmania. Even there, the council clerk said that the cut would create difficulties. The Warden of Circular Head, Councillor O'Halloran, said `the cutback would mean a slight increase in rates'. The Burnie City Council was another cited. Moving to Devonport, Alderman Geoff Squibb said he believed Tasmania was being victimised.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is his political allegiance?

—I think the Minister would have to ask him that himself. I would rather not comment on some of the political allegiances of some of the others. The Warden of the Lyell municipality, Murray Waller, said that `when rates were struck the budget had been cut to a minimum'. They are just some of the examples from the north-west and the west coast of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this Government's blatant disregard for local government has been well documented. I do not wish to take up the Senate's time by repeating that history. I refer to the scrapping of the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations and the introduction of quarterly payments of grants, which was another way in which this Government conned local government. As I said earlier, Senator Reynolds did a very good snow job in that regard. Local governments used to receive their grants in one lump sum and had the opportunity to reinvest the money to their advantage. Now local governments will get it in quarterly payments, so another way of balancing their budgets has been taken away from them.

The receipt of a percentage of funds related to personal income tax-the most equitable way in which local governments had ever received funds-has been scrapped. The recent decision to remove the requirement that Australia Post and Telecom Australia pay local government rates was the greatest con job of all time. Local governments accepted this wonderful idea from Senator Reynolds. She told them, `You will be able to collect from Commonwealth properties the same rates that you charge all other private enterprises and people in the community'. But what happened? It was not very long before the Government decided to claw back and reduce its allocation of funding to those local governments by a very similar amount. The sad thing is that this will affect many country councils that do not have Commonwealth properties in their areas. The Government will reduce the amount of local government funding to the States by roughly the same proportion that local governments will receive in rates from Commonwealth properties. Those municipalities that do not have the advantage of having Commonwealth properties in their areas will be further affected by this measure. It is time that this Government woke up to itself in relation to its commitment to local government. In particular, it is time that the Government recognised why Tasmanian councils are facing the prospect of imposing massive rate hikes on the average ratepayer to absorb Federal cuts.

I listened with interest yesterday to Senator Panizza, a former local government identity from Western Australia. He commented on road funding. I do not intend to give a great discourse on road funding, but one fact that we should keep in mind is that, out of every 23.5c in fuel tax that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is taking at the bowser, local government is receiving 1c to maintain and improve its roads. The State governments receive about 4.95c for their roads. So out of that figure of 23.5c in fuel tax which the Government is thieving from the bowsers, from the people of Australia who are lucky enough to own cars, 1c is being given to local governments to maintain their roads, which are being used more and more these days by people trying to move their goods around the areas. That is another reason why local government is at the moment, and will continue to be, very disenchanted with the performance of this government in the allocation of funds to it. Local government is one of the so-called equal partners, as Senator Reynolds is always telling us. Well, the equal partner is getting a very small part of the cake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this cognate debate on the Appropriation Bills, I want to concentrate on matters that flowed from the Estimates committee hearings, in particular Estimates Committee A, dealing with the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. There were several things which worried members of the Committee and which I think are worthy of bringing to the attention of this chamber in a more detailed form. As a large amount of material was dealt with, I will restrict my remarks and perhaps have an opportunity, during the committee stage, to expound on some points.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin with the Department of Industrial Relations. I will look at the Estimates committee hearings which took place in April 1988, when for the first time an item appeared in the papers put forward for scrutiny for a sum of $9,300-odd which had been paid, or was to be paid, by way of compensation under a code of conduct set up by the Government to deal with industrial problems occurring during the deregulation of the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), particularly in Victoria.

Under that code of conduct, to which employers were required to subscribe, an undertaking was given that compensation would be paid to employers who suffered loss or damage because of harassment from the BLF or from its members. It also excluded from its operation any employers who had been involved in secret commission payments, or anything of that kind, so they were bona fide employers of good faith who were to maintain the law, to operate in the most efficient way they could, and to receive compensation from the Government in the event that they suffered loss.

In April 1988 I asked what action was being taken by the Department to recover that sum of approximately $10,000 from the BLF, which had funds secreted away or banked in some mysterious fashion-at least, the funds were in existence-and I further asked what care and attention was being taken by the Department to recover that money. We did not hear from the Department until just prior to the meeting of Estimates committees in this session. The information that came back was, very simply, that there were no provisions for the Government to recover the money from the BLF because no legal work had been done by the Department to make a binding contract which, either by subrogation or by other contractual means, would enable the Commonwealth to take action against BLF funds.

When I became aware of this advice, which was given by the Australian Government Solicitor, my question was this: was it by accident or design that this money was not able to be recovered from the BLF? That is to say, was it deliberate government policy that this money should not be recovered or was it negligence on the part of the Department which had failed to provide the mechanism to provide the means of getting that money back?

The Minister who was on duty was Senator Button. He undertook to find out whether it was by accident or design; that is, whether it was government policy or negligence on the part of the Department. We have to this date had no reply as to whether it was by accident or design. By persistent questioning of departmental heads, I was able to ascertain, that, far from the rather small sum of $10,000 referred to in April 1988, the projected cost of this scheme was now between $2m and $3m of taxpayers' money. We had gone from finding that a sum of nearly $10,000 had not been recovered to finding that a sum of nearly $3m was not capable of recovery. Interestingly, upon further questioning of departmental officers, I was able to ascertain that the accumulated funds of the BLF were probably also somewhere between $2m and $3m. Had the Commonwealth been able to recoup the money that it had expended because of the action of members of the BLF, those BLF funds would have been effectively wiped out.

I ask again-and I think this chamber is entitled to an answer-whether it was by accident or design. Was it deliberate government policy that prevented legal action being taken concerning the BLF's funds or was it negligence on the part of the Department? Whichever is the answer, neither is satisfactory. It is not satisfactory for the Government to make a political decision that it will spend some $2m to $3m of taxpayers' money without making a provision to get it back from the people who caused the damage in the first place. Neither is it satisfactory to have an answer that it was negligence on the part of the Department, because under the Westminster system obviously the Minister is responsible for ensuring that the proper legal work is carried out to enable action to be taken to recover that money. So we are still waiting with bated breath. Is it accident or is it design? Did the Government deliberately spend some $2m to $3m of taxpayers' money to compensate people for damage caused by the BLF, or was the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, sufficiently negligent in his duty not to have overseen the actions of his Department to ensure that the required legal mechanisms were put in place? That is a matter which remains extant. It is a matter on which we will still press for an answer.

The second matter relating to industrial relations concerns the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. It came to my attention via the well-known grapevine in this place that one senior officer of that Commission commuted regularly between Sydney and Canberra. On my original hearing of the story that took place on a daily basis. However, I was assured that it was not on a daily basis but on a weekly basis, and that this had been going on since some time in October 1987. There has been a change in the head of the Commission in that time, and on cross-examination of witnesses who were giving evidence to the Committee it became apparent that the current Chairman did not approve of this arrangement and would never have sanctioned it. Nonetheless, it was still in place as late as 18 October 1988. I know that because in questioning those officers I asked for further information; that is, for the cost of that commuting, which was incurred simply because the person in question did not wish to move. I asked the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to provide the cost of Canberra-Sydney-Canberra travel, including the travelling allowance, for the Commission's Deputy Director. I asked for that information to be provided separately for the period following the issue of a transfer notice and the period following its withdrawal. The answer which has come back states:
The Deputy Director was, in fact, issued with notification on 16 October 1987 for a fixed term of 3 years from January 1988. The transfer was indefinitely postponed on 8 January 1988.
The amount paid for travel including travelling allowance for the respective periods is as follows:
Period 16 October 1987-7 January 1988-$940.84
Period 8 January 1988-18 October 1988-$22,299.69.

Quite clearly, that is an unconscionable expenditure of public moneys. Quite clearly, and on the evidence given, there was a dissatisfaction with the arrangement expressed by the current head of the Commission. Nonetheless, this arrangement was entered into as early as October 1987 and allowed to drag on to date.

I have further questions: is this arrangement still in place? What is the future of the arrangement? Do any other people have this arrangement? At a time when people are being told that it is necessary to tighten the belt, to make sacrifices, how can the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) possibly sanction the expenditure of $22,299.69 because somebody does not want to move from Canberra to Sydney when he is given a further posting? What sort of scrutiny, what sort of ministerial responsibility, is taken in this matter? We are yet to see whether it is still on foot.

The third matter to which I refer is one that is raised not in the Opposition senators' dissenting or minority report, known as a reservation, and in which the matters to which I have already referred have been raised, but in the body of the report itself. It relates to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and in particular to the offsets and partnership for development programs, a matter which has been the subject of discussion in this chamber on a great number of occasions for the simple reason that there seems in this respect to have been government by press release rather than government by substance. Several things were drawn to the attention of the Committee and came out in fairly strong cross-examination of people who appeared before it. One of the things of concern, which is dealt with in the body of the main report, relates to a practice which seems to have been allowed to develop whereby senior officers from the Department who have been the originators or the instigators of these programs have gone into the private sector taking with them the expertise that they may have gained in the Department, and perhaps specialised knowledge.

Without imputing motives either to future employers or to the people concerned, the important point to be made is this: if the offsets and partnership for development programs are to have any place and are to be of any value, they must been seen as fair dinkum policies, not simply as methods of favouring, or in any way appearing to favour, people who export goods from this country which are purchased by government.

The point I want to stress is this: the offsets and partnership for development programs-which I have to say are suspect in themselves in that there seems to be no initiative on the part of government to make people comply with their offsets commitments, and one could be excused for saying that the partnership for development program might be a mechanism for allowing people to find a way around being involved in the offsets commitment-must be administered scrupulously. There needs to be one set of rules, one set of criteria. To have people leaving the Department and going straight to the private sector-in one case a person was held out as having expertise and having come from that source-so that in some way someone might get a competitive edge, I think, is unacceptable. Attention was drawn to this in the report, and it was pointed out that perhaps some way of preventing such transfers should become part of government policy.

The last matter I want to mention-I will be brief because I hope that at some stage in the future we will have an opportunity to have some sort of full-scale investigation-relates to the Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA). In the reservation report Opposition senators have set out in some detail the consequences that flowed from hearings concerning the ABA that took place on 19 October 1987 when, in answer to a question that I asked of Mr Kirk, the Chairman, about efficiency audits being carried out on the ABA, Mr Kirk advised in evidence that such an efficiency audit had in fact taken place. It was not until the beginning of 1988 when I received correspondence from the Auditor-General's Department informing me that no such efficiency audit had ever taken place, that a rather sad story started to unravel. That simply is this: the ABA has been structured in such a way that the Attorney-General's Department has interpreted that structure as placing the ABA outside the ambit of the Auditor-General to conduct an efficiency audit unless he has permission of the auditee. This is a legal opinion which the Attorney-General has twice given in the sense that he has said that the ABA is not controlled by the Commonwealth. His rather tortuous opinion goes precisely this way: it says that because a majority of the directors of the ABA have not been appointed as individuals by the Commonwealth, somehow the ABA itself is not under the control of the Commonwealth. Prior to the restructuring of the Board it was under the control of the Commonwealth because the Commonwealth appointed all the directors, but when the restructuring took place some of the directors were in fact representative directors of groups and therefore could not be said to be under the direct control of the Commonwealth. That is a spurious argument, to put it mildly.

The same argument was used in respect of the freedom of information (FOI) legislation when, for the same reasons, the Attorney-General said that the ABA was not to be subject to that legislation. That story went even further. Because of that spurious opinion, the Government then sought to table a regulation which took the ABA off the schedule of the freedom of information legislation. That was meant to mean that no applications for FOI could be entertained. When a fuss was made the Government said it would introduce remedial legislation to ensure that the ABA was subject to freedom of information legislation. Having done that, it then made a regulation to take the ABA off the schedule and in its wisdom this Senate disallowed that regulation. Guess what! We have seen no remedial legislation. The ABA is still on the schedule, but it is very selective and very cost-efficient-or rather, cost-officious-as to who shall get information from it and who shall not.

Many sorry stories have emanated from the ABA. Perhaps the most notorious is the story of the First Fleet re-enactment which was denied support and yet miraculously still sailed into Sydney Harbour on Australia Day and made that day in terms of the emotion, the spectacle and the wonder of Sydney Harbour crowded with boats, people and celebrators. But there are more sad and sorry stories. Every day one encounters the dictatorial way in which the ABA has acted towards small people who had a contribution which they thought was worthwhile making. At the beginning of the next century we will celebrate Federation and, again, some sort of body will administer that celebration. There is a need to have some sort of accountability of the ABA in a forum that this Senate may consider suitable. That matter is yet to be determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us have a new flag.

—We certainly will not have a new flag. The final point I want to make is that the ABA has been responsible for the expenditure of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money. It has not been satisfactorily accountable. The regulatory audits which the Auditor-General can and does carry out are not enough. An efficiency audit was needed and it was first asked for in 1986. Only by having efficiency audits and by seeing the manner in which decisions were arrived at, whether they were the right decisions, will we have a satisfactory blueprint in place so that we do not make the same mistakes again. The Estimates committees offer members of this chamber the opportunity to see behind the decisions of government. They are a very important part of the democratic process. I appreciate the opportunity to be able to speak on some of the matters that were important to me and to my fellow senators when we took evidence in this last series of hearings. I look forward to the committee stages of the Appropriation Bills when, perhaps, we can look at other things in more detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 I want to make some remarks on Estimates Committee D. Tonight-it may have even happened earlier-Senator Richardson departed for Brazil to present the World Heritage listing to the World Heritage Bureau. If this listing is accepted by the World Heritage Committee it will have serious ramifications for my State of Queensland. I want to put on record some of the fears and problems that I think should be exposed not only to this Parliament but also, hopefully, to people in the World Heritage Bureau before they make a decision to include a large area of my State in the area under Federal Government control.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1984 I have fought a long and hard battle. In the initial stages of the World Heritage listing we received a number of commitments from the Government, from various Ministers, that the World Heritage listing would not take place unless it had the support of the Queensland Government. In 1984 the Australian Heritage Commission suggested that Australia should nominate the wet tropical rainforests of Queensland for World Heritage listing. In July 1984 State and Federal Government Ministers agreed on future procedures for the listing of World Heritage sites at the meeting of the State Council of Nature and Conservation Ministers. That agreement stated:
The Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.
That is the first broken promise. Only two or three months later, on 12 September 1984, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to the Queensland Premier reinforcing the statement. He said:
It is not the intention of my Government to take unilateral action to nominate the region for World Heritage listing.

That is another broken promise, not only by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) but also by the Prime Minister of this nation, in writing. On 11 February 1986 Senator Ryan, speaking on behalf of the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment, told the Senate:

The Government has made it clear that the wet tropical rainforest of north-east Queensland will only be nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List with the agreement of the Queensland Government.

Never at any time was any agreement given by the Queensland Government to allow the listing of the north Queensland rainforests. For nearly two years the Queensland Government has been saying that it will not accept World Heritage listing, only for it to be pursued by Senator Richardson who is determined to go ahead and list 900,000 hectares of Queensland's rainforests. In a spirit of compromise the Queensland Government said to Senator Richardson that it would accept allocating 60 per cent of the rainforest area for World Heritage listing. Forty per cent was to be under State Government control, and 28 per cent was to be in national parks and timber reserve areas. Only 13.2 per cent of the national rainforest estate would be logged. That was the Queensland Government's compromise, but this was not sufficient for the Federal Government. The recommendations of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) to the World Heritage Commission were:

. . . future management arrangements for the area. The Bureau noted that consultations were under way on the establishment of a joint Commonwealth/Queensland management authority to administer the site which were expected to be completed in September 1988.
The recommendations also stated:

. . . revision of the delimitation of the nominated area in order to make the nomination more coherent. The Bureau considered this revision was required in order to trim the boundaries to make the site a more manageable conservation unit, and to exercise areas where human modification was judged unacceptable and to omit areas which did not contribute significant natural value. . .

That compromise resulted in the Federal Government trimming the boundaries by one per cent. The compromise certainly was not in the spirit of the recommendations. The Federal Government was prepared to offer only one per cent as a compromise to the Queensland Government. Despite the fact that the Queensland Government did not wish to go ahead with World Heritage nomination it made a significant compromise to allow 60 per cent of the World Heritage area to be listed, with 28 per cent to go into national park and timber reserves.

The boundaries were trimmed by one per cent; 31 pieces of land were excised; and eight new areas were included in the boundaries. Those boundaries have never been before this House of Parliament. Those boundaries have no protection under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. I have continually asked Senator Richardson to bring before this Parliament, and to allow for debate, the listing of those boundaries. Senator Richardson has not done that. He is now going to the World Heritage Committee in Paris seeking to nominate boundaries that have not even been before this Parliament. Those boundaries have no protection whatsoever. Only a matter of two or three weeks ago logging was taking place in that unprotected area. Those boundaries have never been before this Parliament and have never received Executive Council approval; yet between 5 December and 8 December the Minister will be seeking in Paris to include those boundaries on the World Heritage List, completely ignoring this Parliament.

We in Australia have a proud record of parliamentary democracy. Yet Senator Richardson is usurping our authority and is seeking to have the World Heritage Committee endorse those boundaries. How can he bypass this Parliament? How can he guarantee that those boundaries will be accepted by the Parliament? Clearly, he is stepping around this Parliament.

Another very important recommendation of the IUCN to the World Heritage Bureau was that it was essential that a joint management authority be established between the Federal Government and the Queensland Government to manage the 900,000 hectares that were to be listed. No joint management authority is in place and there is no plan to take before the World Heritage Committee. Since 30 September this year there have been no negotiations between the State and Federal governments. Since then negotiations have broken down, despite the fact that the Queensland Government suggested in its submission that the nomination cover only 60 per cent of the land and that only 13.4 per cent of the total area be logged.

The Federal Government, with Senator Richardson leading the charge, will present a plan to the World Heritage Bureau in Brasilia. But there is no plan, there is no joint management authority, to manage that vast area. There are no boundaries in place. Senator Richardson should have been forced by his own Party-certainly by Senator Reynolds, who is supposed to represent north Queensland but who is not very effective-to bring the matter before this Parliament so that those boundaries could have been discussed. If the Queensland Government was not prepared to join the Federal Government in submitting a plan to the World Heritage Bureau, legislation should have been brought before this House to give to the Federal Government power to manage that vast area of Queensland under Commonwealth regulation. It should have been debated in this House. It should have been allowed to come into this Parliament.

In answer to a question I asked Senator Richardson only on Friday, he said, `Of course, the Queensland Government will submit. When we get back, World Heritage will be a fait accompli and, if it does not submit and join us in managing that area under a joint management authority, it will not get $75m'. By any criterion that is blackmail in its worst form. When the Queensland Government delegation goes before the World Heritage Bureau in Brasilia, it will show the Bureau a copy of the Hansard to show it what sort of compromise, what sort of spirit of joining together, Senator Richardson showed to allow a joint management authority to manage that vast area. The Bureau will see in that record that Senator Richardson held out $75m and said, `If there is no joint authority, Queensland will not get $75m, and we will not give the people of north Queensland $75m worth of job and industry assistance'. That is blackmail. It cannot be termed anything other than blackmail. I believe the World Heritage Bureau will see it for what it is: the bully-boy tactics of Senator Richardson, trying to ride roughshod over a democratically elected government and, worse than that-if there is anything worse than that-over a democratically elected Federal Parliament.

If Senator Richardson had any honesty about him, he would have brought the issue of the boundaries in here and we would have had the chance to disallow them after 15 sitting days. But no, we were not able to do that. I suspect the reason is that Senator Richardson has been under so much pressure lately from Caucus that he was not game to open the debate in this Federal Parliament again. People on the other side of the chamber are so embarrassed about the loss of 2,000 jobs, the loss of a $33m industry, and the loss of people's homes. Fourth generation, proud forestry workers, people who have the experience and skill to log, are now reduced to picking up papers on the side of the road. I do not believe Senator Richardson had the courage to bring those boundaries before this House and have them debated.

In answer to World Heritage Bureau recommendations, the Government submitted a report called The Wet Tropics of Queensland-A Report to the World Heritage Committee Secretariat in which it said clearly:
If the State Government is unable to participate in co-operative arrangements, the existing interim arrangements will be adapted to provide long-term Federal management arrangements.

In that report a diagram shows how the federal management structure for the wet tropics will work. It shows at the top the Federal Minister responsible for the environment and under him the Director of the federal rainforest agency. Under that is the staff of the federal rainforest agency, with the Community and Scientific Consultative Committee to the left. If Senator Richardson is going to use that federal management structure to manage the 900,000 hectares of rainforest, and if he is not prepared to bring that structure before parliament and have it debated by the democratically elected members-I represent the State of Queensland and I should have a vote on this; Senator Reynolds represents the State of Queensland and she should have a vote on this-he is denying the people of Queensland an opportunity to have a say through their democratically elected representatives.

What is to say that this federal management structure will not be accepted by this Parliament? Senator Richardson is clearly pre-empting the decisions of this Federal Parliament. I hope that the World Heritage Committee will take those two facts into consideration before it makes a decision. In effect, this Government is usurping the decisions and the power of this Parliament if it allows that World Heritage nomination to go forward without the decision being made in this Parliament. That, I believe, will not reflect kindly on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) or on any other committee. I know that UNESCO is embarrassed about the decision to nominate this area for the World Heritage List. It has sent back notes that have come out in publicity saying, `For goodness sake, we are not here to decide Australia's domestic problems'. It is embarrassed about this, and well it should be, because it has been put in the terrible position of one elected government having been overruled by the Federal Parliament of Australia. There is a big power play between Senator Richardson, who will crash or crash through, and the Queensland Government.

Let me put it clearly on the record that the Queensland Government has managed its forests and its rainforests with great skill. That has been acknowledged by some of the best scientific brains in the world. It has been able to sustain the yield of timber coming from the rainforests to provide 2,500 jobs, to provide a $33m industry, and to provide a decent lifestyle for many people, many towns, and many shires. Senator Reynolds sits over there--

SPEECH.PARA: The other area I want to address in my contribution tonight relates to the World Heritage Committee. One of its recommendations was that land owned by Aboriginal people and private citizens and land used for military training should not have World Heritage listing. There is an Aboriginal community just south of Cairns called Yarrabah. Half of the land of that community is going under World Heritage listing. I have received assurances from Senator Richardson that the Aborigines will be able to maintain that land for traditional uses such as cutting timber for their artefacts, housing and so forth. But the Queensland Government is trying to encourage these people to be self-sufficient, to grow things, to run cattle and dairy herds, to use that very good land to develop their own industries. Those people have 8,000 hectares out of their 15,000 hectares locked up. They will never be able to use that land except for traditional purposes. That is not in the best interests of our Aboriginal people. They should be encouraged, as the Queensland Government is encouraging them, to go out and do something with that land-to run cattle, to grow things. But the Government has made sure that 8,000 hectares of that land will never be touched. It will not be able to be used other than to provide a bit of timber to make Aboriginal artefacts.

The whole story of World Heritage listing is very sad because there has been so much misrepresentation; we have compromised the World Heritage Committee. I can understand its having said to Australia, `Please do not send any more of these troubles over for us to sort out. Please do not send your domestic problems over here'. In the last few minutes available to me I say to the World Heritage Committee, as forcefully and with as much enthusiasm as I can, that the Queensland Government has made a compromise: 60 per cent of 900,000 hectares is to be locked away forever under World Heritage listing; 28 per cent of the 900,000 hectares is to go into national parks and timber reserves; and 13.4 per cent is to be logged to sustain 2,000 jobs, to sustain a $33m industry. That is a great compromise by the Queensland Government, in direct opposition to what the Federal Government has done. It has reduced the 980,000 hectares by one per cent. That is the compromise that Senator Richardson has offered.

I say again to the World Heritage Committee: `Do not usurp the Australian people's Parliament. If Senator Richardson wants World Heritage listing let him go to you with boundaries that are accepted by this Parliament. If he wants to manage the World Heritage listing area of 900,000 hectares of north Queensland rainforest, let him go to you with a plan that has gone before the two Houses of Parliament. For the World Heritage Committee to do anything else is clearly usurping and taking away the rights of the Australian people. If those boundaries and the management plan go through the Parliament the Australian people, through their democratically elected representatives, will have had their say and Senator Richardson can go to the Committee fairly and say, `We have put this through the democratic process of the Australian Parliament'. But Senator Richardson can make no such claim. He has bypassed this Parliament. He has squibbed it on the boundaries and on the management authority. He is not game to bring before this Parliament again an open debate on this very contentious issue because the Australian Labor Party is running scared.

I can see the embarrassment when I speak on this issue. People opposite hang their heads in shame, as well they might, when we say to them, `You have taken away the jobs from your fellow unionists, those people who have paid $180 a year to send you here to represent them. You have reduced these people to picking up papers on the side of the road'. Honourable senators opposite hang their heads in shame, and if I were in their position I would be very embarrassed. Senator Richardson has tried to crash through. He has embarrassed his fellow Labor Party colleagues. He has certainly lost two seats in north Queensland for them. Senator Reynolds has sat here and listened to the debate. I have never heard her say one word in support of her north Queensland constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are never in north Queensland; you don't hear me.

—I have made 14 trips to Ravenshoe to tell the people to hang on. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will agree with me when I say that the debate on boundaries and on a management plan should have become before this Parliament before Senator Richardson tried to flog a dead horse before the World Heritage Committee. I think it is an absolute disgrace.
