SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased tonight to participate in this debate on the Appropriation Bills before the Parliament, which are the very important Budget Bills of this Government. In addition, I want to address a number of comments in the course of my speech to the amendment that has been circulated by Senator Chaney. That amendment pays particular regard to just how out of touch the Hawke Labor Government is, its failure in the areas of economic policy and in particular the maladministration in areas such as Aboriginal affairs and the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The amendment that Senator Chaney has distributed on behalf of the Opposition highlights an issue of major concern to me and the constituency of the Northern Territory that I represent; that is, the issue of this Labor Government raising, then dashing, Aboriginal expectations with unrealistic and divisive promises of national land rights and a so-called treaty and the appalling mismanagement, at both ministerial and bureaucratic levels, of Aboriginal affairs. Senator Chaney's amendment, quite rightly, reflects upon community values, the delivery of government services to guarantee improved living standards, and the fact that the Hawke Labor Government is totally out of touch with the general hopes and aspirations of Australian citizens and, in particular, Aboriginal citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last day or so the media has reported that a new Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-Mr Bill Gray-has been appointed. I know Mr Bill Gray, and I am very pleased with his appointment. I believe that he will bring to this position a reputation of not only being, as one newspaper report said, a shrewd, behind-the-scenes operator with a low public profile but also certainly having a great wealth of experience in this portfolio. I know that Mr Gray will be mindful of the events of the last month or so when this issue has attracted such public attention. It has attracted public attention not because of Mr Gray's role but because of the inadequacies of the administration that he has now inherited and because of the lack of control in this area by the Hawke Labor Government and, in particular, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. I will be pleased to work with Mr Gray. I trust that he will take up the mantle and address the very serious problems that have been raised in the last month.

I have had a wealth of correspondence and contact from all over Australia in the last month. I have not counted the number of phone calls, letters and representations that I have received, but they would be in the order of several hundred. Just about everyone has been encouraging the stance that the Opposition has taken in seeking to expose the inadequacies and the maladministration of this portfolio. I refer to one letter from a person I thoroughly respect. He expressed the conviction that some housekeeping was certainly needed and said that he hoped it would go far enough, as earlier inquiries by the Hawke Labor Government had certainly not done so. He went on in his letter to speak of a `new paternalism' that avoids tough action in dealing with Aboriginal administration. That is what I hope Mr Gray will be able to address, particularly as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has now-at last-taken an interest in this portfolio. He has seen the inadequacies that exist in the portfolio. The Prime Minister must now share the concerns about its maladministration.

We also need to guarantee that in the future we develop Aboriginal leadership within Australia that gives to Aboriginal people qualities that we would want in our leadership. Without good leadership, the goals that anybody sets-Mr Gray, as the new departmental head, Mr Hand as the Minister, or the Government-cannot be achieved no matter what their resources are. The leadership that emerges throughout the Aboriginal bureaucracy of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs must reflect sound values. We do not want alcoholics and embezzlers. We are looking for people with sound family backgrounds who are confident in themselves and who have the motivation and commitment to bring total Aboriginal advancement-not just to a particular family clan group, as has so often been the case.

We need to address the fact that a multiplicity of services and their delivery have caused the very problems of lack of government control and past maladministration. It has been reckoned to me by one of the people who have written to me during the month that in the Northern Territory there are some 70 agencies promoting Aboriginal development, and often Aboriginal communities have to face up to 15 of these agencies in any one week. As my correspondent said, how would we get on with a marriage guidance counsellor living with us in our lounge room? He said, `I reckon we would be divorced in no time'. That is what has happened in the last month or so. In the Senate Estimates Committee D hearings we have been able to divorce, at last, some of these issues from the Minister, Mr Hand. He has acted as the marriage guidance counsellor with a paternalism whereby he has sought to sit in the lounge rooms, or the humpies, of Aboriginal people living in remote communities. It is this paternalism that I was attacking.

Prior to the Senate Estimates Committee hearings over a month ago, I put some 400 questions on notice. During the hearings of the Senate Estimates Committee, I tackled 250 additional questions. My colleagues Senator Durack and Senator Short also took up a number of other issues just as I know you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and Senator Boswell, in the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, have also been actively pursuing these issues, issues that need to be addressed. What has been the final Government response? We now have seven inquiries in place into the administration of Aboriginal affairs. The Government did not have the guts or the courage to face up to the judicial inquiry that the Opposition called for and felt was most needed. Instead, it put in place four Public Service inquiries. It called in the Auditor-General. It called in the Public Service Commissioner. It called in the Department of Finance special investigator. It called in a Mr Menzies to look at the other issues. All of these inquiries will be fine. They will flow through, I hope, with public reports to this Parliament early next year. The issues that have been raised are so serious that they must be debated here subsequently. We have not yet been given that assurance. Anybody who wants to make submissions to any of these four inquiries does not enjoy the protection they could have enjoyed had there been a judicial and independent inquiry. Again, the Government is resorting to a camouflage.

In addition, there are three parliamentary inquiries under way. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and Senator Boswell, as I have said, serve on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. This Committee was brought about because the Labor Government was attempting to bulldoze through this Parliament proposals for a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) that were totally out of kilter with the Australian community and certainly out of balance with the Aboriginal community. A special Senate inquiry is now necessary into several matters of privilege that have arisen from the Estimates hearings. In addition, the House of Representatives, through its Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, has in place a committee that is looking into the infrastructure of community services for Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

Seven inquiries are currently necessary because of the total inadequacy in addressing this portfolio by Mr Hand and the Labor Government. Is it any wonder that staff are resigning in droves from Department of Aboriginal Affairs offices throughout Australia and from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC)? How can these senior public servants, who have given a lifetime of commitment to the Australian Government, look back on their careers and plan for their futures and the contribution they want to make when they are aware that this Government has had absolutely no confidence or any record of achievement in this portfolio in the last five years?

In the House of Representatives the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) have continually taken the line that Senator Short and I, by being very active in our questioning on this issue in the Estimates Committee, were abusing our position of privilege. Mr Snowdon said on 24 November:
Over the last few weeks he-
he was referring to me-

has undertaken a campaign, along with his colleagues, deliberately to belittle people and has demonstrated a clear lack of integrity by using his position of privilege in the Senate in a way which I can only describe as jumping into the gutter of racial division and character assassination for cheap and cynical political point scoring.

What utter, absolute, blatant rubbish! At no time has Mr Snowdon or Mr Hand attempted to come in with constructive and proper reactions to those issues that we were raising. There was no attempt to create racial division or to engage in character assassination whatsoever. If people got caught up in the maladministration and were named, they have to live with the consequences. It is for this Labor Government to walk away from its racist attitudes because it has set out on a policy of separatism, of separate development of Aboriginal people, out of kilter with the rest of Australia. When some of us jump and say, `Hey, this is the line you are taking', what does the Government do? It says that we are smearing all Aboriginals. What utter and absolute rubbish!

Minister Hand's response has been a weak cover-up of only part of the problem. It is still a national scandal. The fact that Mr Hawke, behind the Minister's back, has had to resort to four Public Service inquiries, plus of course the three parliamentary ones, highlights the particular problems. The lousy and inefficient administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs by the then Secretary, Charles Perkins, is still suspiciously overlooked. Where is the support or the loyalty for the genuinely hard-working staff-the great majority-throughout the portfolio? What this Government has failed to do is to see the poverty, the illiteracy and the poor health of Aboriginal people throughout Australia. Instead, it has been concentrating on political power games and not fixing the very desperate needs.

The reports of the Senate Estimates Committee highlight this problem in great detail. The majority report identified many of the areas where there needed to be savings. It identified areas in departmental administration where there also needed to be an improvement in recruiting and staffing practices. It also identified areas where there is abuse of departmental resources. The Committee recommended that a number of issues that were raised, most importantly, by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA)-the major Public Service union of Australia-needed to be addressed. Mr Hand had flippantly picked up the ACOA letter and responded to it without referring it properly to the Department for corrective action. That ACOA letter-I am sure my colleague Senator Short will refer to it in more detail when he speaks in this debate-referred to recruitment and staffing practices; the malpractices which were not regularly disclosed; the alarming loss of morale that is claimed by some officers to lead to conspicuous inefficiencies; the recruitment by unconventional means of public servants who were not competent to perform their duties; the misuse of travelling allowances and financial provisions; and the issue of patronage.

They were all issues raised by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. We addressed them in a Senate select committee, which is the proper and appropriate place to do it. What do the Minister, Mr Hand, and Mr Snowdon do about it? They get up and say we are smearing Aboriginals. How far from the truth can one go? They cannot see what they are looking at.

A number of issues have been raised and there is no reason for any group, Aboriginal or otherwise, to resort to excuses. We drew attention to a whole series of scandals and rorts that reflected on the maladministration by Mr Hand and, to a certain extent, by Mr Perkins. Of course, Perkins took the chop because the Minister did not want to face up to the embarrassment of what he should have done and publicly resign. Mr Perkins took the chop as a result of what had happened at the Woden Town Club in terms of poker machines. Certainly that major scandal was a factor. But Mr Hand was also totally involved and had been briefed on it from day one. He could not tell the difference between a loan guarantee and a grant. He kept hiding behind the fact that he thought a loan guarantee was not going to be called up. Of course we all know that it was called up. In the end the Government, through the Aboriginal Development Commission, put over $900,000 into its Aboriginal social club in Canberra. What lousy, rotten priorities when there are people dying in outback Australia, when there are people living in dreadful housing conditions and when the illiteracy of Aboriginal children still has to be addressed.

Other scandals have been made public over the last month. Directors of various companies have been playing ducks and drakes in respect of the Nardoola property. The Oasis Hotel was given away as a result of action by Mr Perkins. I have spoken previously in the Senate chamber about the Charleville Housing Association in Queensland. The Association was directed by Sugar Ray Robinson, a most unsavoury character and a confidant of both the Minister, Mr Hand, and the Secretary, Mr Perkins.

The Middair company in Western Australia, which was involved in the promotion of Aboriginal dance, is again another unresolved issue. Tranby College in Sydney, into which $500,000 of taxpayers' funds was channelled, was used by the Government to sell a treaty around Australia. This is another scandal. I have just received in recent days answers to a number of questions raised. One of the questions I put on notice was:
In legal terms under the ADC Act, is Tranby College a body with which the ADC could have dealings:
What is the answer? The answer is:
In legal terms, no. The College does not meet the Aboriginal objects clause required under Section 4 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.

Yet half a million dollars has been committed to enable that organisation to go out and promote a treaty. Of course Tranby College has had dubious connections with the left wing union politics of Australia. It has tenuous octopus links with Cuba and Nicaragua.

The network of mates and cronies run by Mr Perkins and Mr Hand defies description. Undue influence was certainly used continually in the administration of this Department at the expense of the Aboriginal people who are being denied housing, health and proper education. The recent sit-in at the ADC office after Mr Perkins was sacked, of course, highlighted the problem. What did some of Mr Hand's acquaintances do? They went out and bought cheese, biscuits and cakes for the people who were engaging in an illegal demonstration in a government office. They also gave them open access to telephones. Is that any way to carry on?

As I said earlier, I have received dozens, if not hundreds, of submissions, the vast majority of which I am passing directly to the Auditor-General because I cannot trust the Minister, Mr Hand, to deal with them properly. I am passing them straight to the Auditor-General for investigation. To give an example of just how serious this involvement is, let me quote from one of those submissions. A 69-page submission concludes:

We have made this submission as private citizens and due to the potential threat of violence to our immediate families we trust that you will ensure that the source of this information remains confidential.

I tore the names and addresses of those people off the bottom of that document before I passed it on to the Public Service Commissioner and the Auditor-General. These people, who feel so seriously about this issue, are employees of this Government.

The Aboriginal Development Commission was functioning very well before May 1988. Minister Hand did not like the way in which it was putting up alternative views about a particular thing. He was saying that he wanted Government and community consultation with Aboriginal people. So he walked in and he sacked all of the commissioners that he had the power to sack. He threw them out. What happened? The eight new commissioners that were appointed did not file their pecuniary interest forms until after the Senate Estimates committee hearings in the last month. In fact, Mr Perkins did not even file his until after he was sacked-and that became apparent through the questioning.

These people operated totally unprofessionally and without any regard to their position. At the Senate Estimates Committee hearings it was obvious to us that they operated without proper paperwork and without looking at things in detail. There was a great deal of intimidation of the Chairman, Mrs McPherson, who is one of the most outstanding Aboriginal leaders in Australia. She has had the courage to stand up to Minister Hand, stick by her principles and hold her position. What has she copped in return? She has copped nothing but denigration, lack of support and in fact smear. The General Manager of the ADC, Mr Mick O'Brien, has been pushed around. He has been accused of all sorts of unsavoury and unnecessary actions.

Not only were there peculiar circumstances surrounding the board meetings for the last six months but there were also very suspicious circumstances with regard to the appointment of the new Acting General Manager, when a crony of Mr Perkins, grabbed out of the Perth office, was pushed into that acting position as part of the duckshoving. Of course, it is very questionable who knew what and whether involvement in this matter reached right into the Minister's office. There are just so many interesting revelations that we should be looking at in this whole area of waste and maladministration.

As I continue to say, the people who are missing out because of the wastage and the duplication of funds are the Aboriginal communities. Of the 230,000 Aboriginal people around Australia, some 60,000 live traditional lifestyles in outback Australia. The balance, of course, are to a large extent urbanised. There is, of course, a very big inbuilt conflict between the traditional and the Aboriginal administration of this port- folio. That is what the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner was all about. It was a power grab for left wing political control-and let us not ever try to camouflage this. One has only to look at the new system of regions and zones that was to be created in the new ATSIC. They were out of kilter with every principle that the Australian Labor Party has ever stood for and has ever put forward in this place and the House of Representatives.

The Government went to a referendum earlier this year on one vote one value. There is nothing like that, of course, for Aboriginals. The discrepancies in the size and control and the vote rigging that would have taken place had ATSIC proceeded in the form in which it was put forward would have meant that Mr Hand and his left wing union mates had total control of $800m that was to be pushed by the Labor Government off the Budget out to a statutory authority and controlled in a very different manner. So it would not have mattered whether Australia had a right wing Hawke Labor government or whether we subsequently had a Liberal-National Party government in its place; Hand was out to ensure that that $800m to $1,000m was pushed off the Budget and out to totally independent control.

Honourable senators should read the various submissions that were made since last December, when Mr Hand first put up a study document called Foundations for the Future. Two options came forward in the early part of the year. In May the Minister decided he had to get rid of the alternative Aboriginal voice that was emerging through the Aboriginal Development Commission and he sacked eight proper Aboriginal leaders around Australia and put in eight cronies that he could totally control. To take it one step further, in June at the Burunga festival near Katherine in the Northern Territory the Prime Minister had a ring put in his nose, he was led around the circus ring and the promise of a treaty was made. A week later at the ADC meeting one of Mr Hand's new appointees on the ADC, Pat Dodson, was appointed by Perkins, another new Hand ADC commissioner, to control the distribution of $500,000 for the purpose of negotiating a new treaty with Aboriginal people. What has happened to that treaty? All we know is that about $200,000 of that money seems to have filtered away and disappeared through Tranby College, through a couple of community meetings. Where is the rest of it? Where is the commitment to Aboriginal people around Australia? What is standing in line? It is only the lefties that have gained any advantage at this particular time. There was a total sham of consultation.

If honourable senators take the time to read a series of questions that I put on notice through the other Senate Estimates committees they will see that this new ATSIC was being forced through by a Labor government, or by a couple of Ministers. Obviously Gerry Hand and Bob Hawke had walked into Cabinet and said, `Trust us. We've got the goods; we'll do it'. Senator Reynolds, Senator Walsh, Senator Richardson and all of the other Ministers sat back and said, `Yes, we trust you, Gerry; we trust you, Bob'. What has come out in the answers to all of those other questions is that even the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance, the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Local Government and so many other government departments were not aware of the fundamental principles of ATSIC and how things were going to change.

I am pleased that in recent days the Prime Minister has said that the Government is rethinking its position. It is rethinking its position only because the voice of genuine Aboriginal people out there in outback Australia is at last being heard, and not in a paternalistic way. Gerry Hand may have walked around and consulted with more people than any government has ever done before, but he spoke at them; he did not speak with them. He did not listen for replies; he did not wait for the alternative view. He sacked the people who gave him alternative views. That was probably the most crucial thing. Of course, this Hawke Labor Government does not consult with the other interested parties, such as the State and Territory governments and the industry groups that would be affected by such a major proposal involving the shifting of $800m to $1,000m off Budget.

I am also very pleased to note that in very recent days alternative land councils in regions in the Northern Territory are seeking to break away from those stacked groups that are already there in the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. Maybe the one good thing the Hawke Labor Government has done is to make sure that Imparja Television got mobile through Alice Springs, because the Aboriginal community throughout Australia is now seeing what this Government is up to. It is now seeing the debate between traditional and urban Aborigines, the debate between authority and autonomy, and the debate between proper decisions and the gangs of four, whether they are in the Minister's office, the ADC, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or the Northern Land Council.

These gangs of four lefties seem to be in place everywhere. The suspicious networks that Hand and Perkins have set up have now meant that Aboriginal people themselves are demanding alternative breakaway land councils. The Aboriginal Cultural Foundation is singing out on the traditional issues of northern Australia, and community government, which is local government by Aboriginal people closest to the people, is emerging. The South Australian Government, the Northern Territory Government, the Queensland Government and hopefully the Western Australian Government will shortly address this matter. Community government is the way to go-not these fancy, biased proposals of the Hawke Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills has been very protracted. The debate was preceded by very detailed questioning of each department's appropriations in the hearings of the six Senate Estimates committees. This second reading debate will no doubt be followed by further detailed consideration when we are in the Committee of the Whole. In my remarks tonight I want to spend much of my time on the subject of the Government's policy towards and its administration of Aboriginal affairs. I fully acknowledge the magnificent speech made by Senator Tambling tonight. The work that he has done in this area, in particular during Estimates committee hearings over recent weeks, has been of enormous benefit to this Parliament because of the very great importance of the matters that primarily he has raised, with the support of many other people, including Senator Peter Baume and Senator Boswell, who are members of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I was pleased to join Senator Tambling in the discussion of these matters by Senate Estimates Committee E.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to Senator Tambling for the work that he has done in this area. The work was not done just to make a political point; indeed, the contrary was the case. What we are really talking about is how best we as a nation can further the progress and development of a section of our community which we all-whether we are Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal-regard, accept and know is amongst the least privileged and the most deprived. The sad thing that has been happening in Australia over many years, particularly under the policies and administration of this Government, has been that Aboriginal communities have suffered very grievously.

I want to direct most of my remarks tonight to this area. It was the major issue considered by Senate Estimates Committee E, of which I was a member. That Estimates Committee also considered the appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and the Department of Administrative Services. I will reserve most of my comments on these departments to the committee stage. However, I wish to touch on some aspects of these departments in tonight's debate.

I also want to refer briefly to the economic environment in which this debate is occurring. The current state of the Australian economy is one of grave concern to us all-or it certainly should be. However, the more that I hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other senior Ministers pontificating, the more I doubt whether they appreciate this quite fundamental point. To listen to Ministers Hawke and Keating and Senators Button and Walsh, one could be forgiven for thinking that the Australian economy was on the right course. Nothing could be further from the truth. The basic parameters around which the Budget was framed just three months ago are now fatally flawed. I refer in particular to Australia's inflation rate, the balance of payments deficit and the level of interest rates. These are, of course, all interrelated. The Budget forecast for inflation in 1988-89 was about 5 1/2 per cent for the year as a whole, and there was a projection of an annual rate of 4 1/2 per cent by the June 1989 quarter. In fact, on the latest figures, inflation is running at an annual rate of 7.3 per cent. It is more likely to rise than to fall in the months ahead.

There is no way that the Budget Papers forecasts will be met. They will be exceeded, in my view, by at least 2 per cent. In other words, inflation in 1988-89 will be two-fifths higher than forecast. Similarly, with regard to the balance of payments deficit on the current account, the Budget forecast a current account deficit of $9.5 billion this year. Already, after only four months, the deficit is $5.4 billion-an average monthly deficit over those four months of $1.35 billion. For the full year figure to come out at the forecast of $9.5 billion, the monthly deficit over the remaining eight months would have to average almost one-third of that figure-$510m per month. Even allowing for seasonal and other factors, that figure is impossible to achieve. The current 1988-89 current account deficit will exceed the Budget forecast by at least $2 billion. On this basis it will be as large as it was in 1987-88, and quite possibly a deal larger.

On any objective assessment, the Australian dollar is overpriced. In fact, its value is rising rather than falling. There are several reasons for this seemingly perverse performance. One, of course, is the weakness of the United States dollar; but the overriding reason is the level of interest rates in Australia. The Government has deliberately engineered a large rise in rates in recent months. It sees this as one means of cooling demand in the economy. Also, the authorities fear a cost-price induced increase in inflation if they let the Australian dollar fall back to a level more in line with our underlying competitive position.

This policy is fraught with danger and is totally inequitable. It hits every home buyer in the country, particularly young couples striving to buy their own homes. Repayments on an average home loan have gone up astronomically under this Government, by 70 per cent and more in many instances. Higher interest rates also hit productive enterprises and investment, because they increase costs. This will have a damaging effect on the structure of the economy and on the rate of inflation. The effect on inflation could well be more severe than would be the case if interest rates were lower, thereby allowing the Australian dollar to fall. At the same time, of course, exporters would not be disadvantaged-some very grievously-as they are at the moment with the current high level of the Australian dollar.

The existing high interest rate monetary policy is being imposed at a time when the overall economy is not as strong as the Government would have us believe. Today's national accounts figures for the September quarter clearly indicate that. A rise of only 0.3 per cent in real gross domestic product in the September quarter and a fall of 3.2 per cent in private fixed investment in equipment are hardly signs of a booming economy. The latest retail sales figures released yesterday support this view.

I do not want to say any more about the economy at this stage, other than to say that the Government's ill-conceived economic policy is simply a product of the Government's failure to take the tough economic decisions to get this economy going and growing and internationally competitive. On those grounds, we are going backwards and our actual productivity is declining. In the last year it declined by approximately 1.4 per cent in absolute terms. Against the rest of the world, of course, our productivity is down much more than that. Until the Government reduces its own avaricious demands on goods and services, and therefore on taxpayers, who now face a crippling taxation burden; until it takes measures to increase our productivity by tackling the real problems of an inflexible wages policy and other labour market rigidities, gross inefficiencies on the waterfront, and the freeing up to greater competition and privatisation of government owned businesses, the Australian economy will continue to limp along while the living standards of all Australians continue to decline especially in comparison with the rest of the world.

Let me now say something about two other issues which I believe are of great concern in their very different ways. These two issues, together with that of Aboriginal affairs, on which I will conclude my remarks, although different, sum up very cogently one of the basic weaknesses of this Government. That weakness is a total inability to develop and administer a coherent set of priorities geared to the real needs of this nation as we approach the end of the twentieth century.

One of the two matters to which I refer is the Government's proposals to introduce a new War Crimes Act. During the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee E I was appalled to find an apparent lack of appreciation amongst departmental officials of the sensitivity of this issue and of its scope to cause massive division within the Australian community. I was also appalled at the lack of concern shown by both the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, and departmental officials. I am concerned that there is a dangerous cloak being thrown over the activities of the special investigator, Mr Greenwood. Denials are being made that people have been interrogated, but I actually know people who know people who have been interrogated.

It is essential that the Government come clean about just what is going on. The number of people being investigated seems to vary day by day. We were told in the Senate Estimates Committee that the figure was now 414. I have seen reports in recent days that the investigator says it is about 550. No-one is prepared to tell us when the special investigator will complete his investigations, whom he is talking with or what arrangements he may be making with other countries. Instead, the office of the special investigator was not even represented at the Estimates hearings. Many grave doubts are increasingly being held by an increasing number of people in the community about these war crimes proposals. It is essential that the Government come clean about all the details. Instead, it spends a very large amount of taxpayers' money on the preliminary investigations, while average Australians grow poorer daily because of the inept management and policies of this Government-a government incapable of setting priorities in accordance with the needs of this nation and its people, a government still hell-bent on financial profligacy and socialist directions.

The second issue I want to raise briefly concerns the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). Again, the treatment the Government is according the NCSC is a classic example of just how out of touch this arrogant, tired Government is with the real needs of Australia. The NCSC is our corporate watchdog. It was established by the Fraser Government in the late 1970s as the linchpin of the cooperative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States to promote commercial certainty, to reduce business costs, to improve efficiency and to maintain investors' confidence in our securities markets. That is an enormous task. It is also enormously important, particularly at the moment. The NCSC has a huge workload on its hands, as it has had for the past year or so. It has looked at such matters as the Bond group takeover of the Bell Group Ltd, the IEL takeover of Woolworths Ltd and the share dealings by the Bell Group and Elders in relation to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. It is now conducting inquiries into Rothwells Ltd, into that scandalous situation concerning the whole of the Western Australian Government now known, and appropriately so, as Western Australia Inc.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia Red Ink.

—Or Western Australia Red Ink, as Senator Michael so rightly says. It is a scandal which has involved taxpayers' money by the squillions. There is no doubt that, as those investigations go ahead, the corruption that will be found to exist in Western Australia will make the situation in other parts of Australia look like chickenfeed. The NCSC is also conducting inquiries into Ariadne-again a very complex inquiry-yet it is starved of resources.

SPEECH.PARA: This year-in 1988-89-there is a budgeted fall of 4 per cent in real terms in the amount of funds available to the NCSC. The Executive Director of the NCSC, Mr Ray Schoer, when I asked him at the Estimates hearings about the Commission's resources compared with those a year earlier, said that it was having difficulty then in keeping up with the range of things it was supposed to be doing, and that its workload had increased massively since. He said in response that the situation `has deteriorated, the situation is worse'. That is an extraordinary sense of priorities by this Government. Why is it acting in this way in relation to the NCSC? I believe it is acting in this way to cause the denigration of the NCSC in a desperate and quite unscrupulous bid to win support for its huge package of centralist, socialist proposals to establish a new raft of regulatory arrangements for the management and regulation of securities industries in Australia, where the real power would reside in bureaucratic hands in Canberra. There has been a complete lack of consultation between the Government and industry on this matter. Fortunately the Senate has had the good sense to set up, along with the House of Representatives, a joint select committee to examine this huge package of proposals, the largest ever seen in Australia's legislative history. The Senate is going to have a very important role indeed in the examination of these matters.

Finally, I want to speak about the Hawke Government's policy towards, and its administration of, Aboriginal affairs in this country. I acknowledge at the outset that this is not an area in which I have been closely involved in the past. Members of parliament cannot get across each and every area of involvement by the Federal Government. My attention has tended in the past to be focused on matters other than Aboriginal affairs. My present interest and involvement in Aboriginal affairs has been occasioned by my membership of Estimates Committee E.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good member too.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne; I acknowledge that. It has the responsibility for exercising and examining the appropriations for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). As I said at the outset of my remarks, I pay very high tribute to the work of Senator Tambling on Estimates Committee E, and to the work of other senators on my side of politics who have been involved over many years in the examination of, and policy towards, Aboriginal affairs. In particular I pay tribute to Senator Peter Baume and Senator Fred Chaney, both of whom have been Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs in coalition governments.

SPEECH.PARA: I am dismayed at what was revealed at the recent hearings of the Estimates Committee. Since then I have read more widely. Had I done so earlier, perhaps I would simply have been dismayed earlier, because the policy direction and the administration of Aboriginal affairs have been in an appalling state for years under this Government. Of even greater concern, the situation has deteriorated progressively and rapidly over those years. I do not place all the blame on the shoulders of the present Government. The Fraser Government was not blameless. Aboriginal affairs is an extraordinarily difficult area to administer and in which to find a proper basis for policy direction. The Fraser Government did not get it totally right, nor, of course, did the Whitlam Government. Indeed, that Government in many ways put us on the fatal path on which the Hawke Government has built.

I remember in the second half of the 1970s having to examine, along with Senator Michael Baume, the disasters that occurred in the Aboriginal affairs area under the administration of the Whitlam Government. People will remember such things as the turtle farms that never had a chance of economic viability, the promises that were made to the Aboriginal people that were broken before the ink was dry, and so on. Many aspects of the present situation concern and dismay me. They fall into two categories: firstly, the policy framework, and, secondly, the administration of that framework. The two are interrelated, but I will try to separate them for the purposes of exposition.

The policy framework is obviously wrong. One can say that categorically by just looking at the facts. In the five years since the Hawke Government came to office it has allocated $3.3 billion to Aboriginal affairs. That is a huge amount of money by any standards. Its enormity is even more apparent when one considers the relatively small size of the Aboriginal population in Australia. I am not certain what the claimed Aboriginal population in Australia is, but on rough figures that outlay of $3.3 billion would have to constitute for every Aboriginal man, woman and child a minimum of about $10,000 over that period. Different people have different views about the result but I do not know of anyone in the community who would say that the Aboriginal people are in a better state than they were at the start of this Government's administration. In that sense I draw support from the answer given by the Aboriginal Development Commission to a question put on notice by Senator Tambling in Senate Estimates Committee E. When it was asked about the disparity in the economic status of Aboriginals and other Australians, the Aboriginal Development Commission responded in writing. It said:
ADC concerns that the disparity between the economic status of Aboriginals and other Australians is continuing to widen is supported by the fact that:-
National average weekly male earnings (NAWMEs) of the two groups has continued to widen marginally.
Aboriginal NAWMEs includes a higher element of dependency on unemployment benefits and CDEP payments.
The level of unemployment among Aboriginals decreases more slowly than for other Australians.
In certain areas unemployment among Aboriginals is increasing because of:
continuing decline in employment opportunities as a result of mechanisation and structural changes in primary industry
the inadequacy of education and training resulting in a higher percentage of Aboriginals being dependent in lower paid, less-skilled or unskilled employment
employment opportunities for Aboriginals being fewer because of this and the limited employment available in areas, particularly rural, where most Aboriginals live.
ADC experience-
and the Commission is right at the grassroots of the Aboriginal communities in this country-
is that Aboriginals need greater access to finance, professional assistance, and commercial guidance.

Those are some answers from the ADC as to what is happening as a result of the policies of this Government. Recently, a study was completed by Professor Malcolm Treadgold, who is the professor of economics at the University of New England. After a very detailed study of the period from 1976 to 1986 he produced a report which came to certain conclusions. In a radio interview Professor Treadgold said:
. . . hundreds of millions of dollars which have been poured into promoting Aboriginal welfare and employment have not improved their relative economic position in the community.

He gave the reasons for that but I will not go into all the details, other than to reiterate the basic message that, despite the huge amount of funding that has gone into Aboriginal affairs over the last five years under this Government, the position of Aborigines within the Australian society has deteriorated rather than improved.

The same is so in relation to health. Just recently a study was concluded by the Australian Institute of Health and included in its biennial report. It found that the mortality rate of young and middle-aged Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders has improved only marginally in 10 years and is now comparable with mortality rates in places such as Haiti, Ghana and India. The study said that the mortality rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children is double the national average. It also said that all these figures were of particular importance because Aboriginal health programs had been fragmented and poorly coordinated. That is a criticism that must be levelled fairly and squarely at the present Government.

The direction of policy has been wrong in the whole area of Aboriginal affairs. If the Government gets its way and abolishes the existing Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission and puts in their place a huge new bureaucratic structure known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), that wrong direction will be compounded. This would mean the creation of something like 58 to 60 new regional councils, and the administration problems would be absolutely horrendous. At the same time, though, the new structure removes some checks and balances in the administrative procedures and gives the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) a veto over the activities of the Commission in a way which would completely remove the need and the basic desirability of Aboriginal people being responsible for their own decision making.

Because there were opposing views to the creation of this new monstrosity virtually all the directors and the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission were sacked by the present Minister in May, and the reason they were sacked was that they dared to express views about ATSIC that were contrary to those of this Government. In the construction of the ATSIC proposals there has been a complete lack of consultation between the Government and the Aboriginal communities around Australia; so the attempt to establish this Commission has been lamentable. The worst thing about the proposal is that it divides Australia. The Government believes that having this new Commission is good because it represents the first major attempt in our history to provide a formal framework through which Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders can influence government decisions which affect them and their interests. If and when the Bill becomes law, it will mean one thing above all others. Professor Colin Howard, Professor of Law at Melbourne University, said that the Bill:

aims to set up an organisation closely resembling a miniparliament for the sole use and advantage of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. What this will mean is that a section of the Australian population will have been singled out by reference to race for separate representation based on a separate voting roll.
He continues that the Bill-

if it becomes law, will have revealed us as being as racist as anyone else. We should not be in the business of deliberately creating a sub-nation with a sub-parliament with enormous powers to claim land and other property as its own. Whatever the motives, this is a recipe for racial disaster.
I strongly agree with the view of Professor Howard on that matter.

The administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission has been very well explained and set out tonight by Senator Tambling. I will not go over his words other than to repeat that the waste and inefficiencies that have been shown up in the administration of this Department are quite scandalous. I believe that Charles Perkins was sacked as a scapegoat for the preceding and present Ministers of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding and Mr Hand. They have a great deal to answer for to the Australian community. That was made clear in part by a letter forwarded last year to Mr Hand, which was not properly replied to, from the President of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA). I seek leave to incorporate that letter and the reply from the Minister in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
Dear Mr Hand,

I am writing to you to express ACOA's concern about aspects of the administration of your Department. This concern derives from formal resolutions of meetings as well as from individual representations from members. When these are considered in the light of correspondence and meetings between ACOA and Departmental management, their seriousness is compounded.

The threshold issue of consultation with ACOA has, I think, been resolved with the Secretary's undertaking to be responsible for such consultation at the National level. (It is inappropriate for the Secretary to consult local workplace representatives on other than purely local matters.) I have no current complaint about the adequacy of consultation.

There are, however, fundamental issues which I believe require Ministerial attention. This need is emphasised by the projected over-run on the salaries vote this year, by the new APS structure and associated changes described in the 2nd Tier Wages agreement, and by the impending establishment of an Australian Aboriginal Commission.

The issue from which most others derive, as I see it, is that of recruitment and staffing practices. I have no hesitation in asserting that people have been recruited to the staff of the Department by a number of processes not provided for even in the special provisions established to facilitate entry of Aboriginal personnel. Further, my understanding is that some people so recruited have no unique position number, and some have no ASL cover.
It is clear from my unsuccessful attempts to quantify this problem that:

(a) malpractices are not regularly disclosed by other officers of the Department either because they themselves may be compromised or through fear of reprisals, or because they do not wish to appear to be, or be identified as, racist, or as betrayers of the Aboriginal cause.
(b) the existence of such malpractices is widely, if not universally, acknowledged within the Department.
(c) these practices have led to an alarming loss of morale which is claimed by some officers to lead to conspicuous inefficiency.
(d) some people recruited by unconventional means are not competent to perform the duties they have allegedly been recruited to perform. Some do not even attend work on a regular basis.

(e) many people recruited to clerical assistant or basegrade clerical jobs are given positions where they are acting in higher duties in the clerical administrative structure without competitive assessment of their suitability and without training to provide the requisite skills. It is claimed that some are even acting on a partial-performance basis whilst being paid for full performance. Along with most other officers acting on higher duties in the APS, these people will become substantive at the level at which they are acting when the 2nd Tier Wage agreement is ratified in the near future by the Arbitration Commission.

(f) there is a widespread desire within the Department to have the recruitment/promotion/higher duties situation cleaned up and conducted on a proper basis. The current situation brings the Department and its officers into disrepute with the communities it is supposed to serve efficiently and effectively. The very many competent, hard working and dedicated officers, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, who care about the quality of service provided by the Department are having their efforts and their career opportunities undermined while these unconventional practices continue.

The situation seems to me to require thorough internal but independent investigation before loyalties are stretched too far and a wider more public investigation becomes necessary. Tensions have been raised a significant amount by the current requirement to find $1-$1.5 million dollars to be saved on the salaries bill by 30 June 1988. In this climate, the conduct of Aboriginal-only staff meetings is most unfortunate, and I trust you will put an end to this practice.

Also arising from the current discussion throughout the Department on the salaries over-run question, a number of cases of alleged misuse of the travelling allowance and other financial provisions have been reported to me. I am reluctant to specify these as I am not aware that they are of the same widespread and general nature as the recruitment/promotion/HDA situation, and hence the locations of my informants may be identifiable. There is genuine concern about reprisal action being taken against complainants. However, in general terms, there is concern about the use of accommodation paid for by the Department by people not entitled to it, the acquisition by the Department of one or more camper-trailers not available for general Departmental use, the provision of travelling expenses including TA to people not on necessary Departmental business, payment for consultants who have not delivered an identifiable service, and other matters.

Whilst I do not argue that the Department ought not make payments of the kind referred to, I most strongly do argue that such moneys should be separately identified in the Department's financial estimates and records and be processed in an open and proper manner. It is unacceptable to ask public servants to do their jobs in ways they know or believe to be wrong, and designed to mask the purpose for which public moneys have been spent.

The issue of patronage is raised by some aspects of the matters raised in this letter. Whilst I recognise that is a very difficult question for any and every Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I must insist that it cannot be resolved by removal from the political arena, to be placed on the shoulders and the consciences of public servants. Some at least of those public servants have had enough. The practices of DAA must be brought into line with the requirements of legislation, regulations and other government directives and awards of the C&A Commission. Where these are incompatible with the practical requirements of administering this difficult and sensitive portfolio, then special provision must be made by Government to resolve the problem. This already happens in some areas, such as recruitment, in which instance even these special provisions are not adhered to. The creation of an Australian Aboriginal Commission presents an opportunity to make a fresh start in respect of the fundamental issue of accountability. It also presents an opportunity for issues involved in the current crisis to get right out of hand, to the great detriment of the Aboriginal people. I look forward to an early opportunity to discuss this and related matters with you.

Should you wish to be briefed on the special provisions which apply to the recruitment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people to the Public Service, I strongly recommend that you seek such a briefing from the Equal Employment Opportunity Unit in the Public Service Commission, the Director of which is Ms. Gail Radford. The unit is able to provide the most expert and authoritative advice available on this matter in the Public Service.
Please contact me if you wish to discuss any matter with me, whether raised in this letter or not.
Yours sincerely,
Ann Forward
National President
Dear Ms Forward
I refer to your letter of 6 November, which makes a number of serious and disturbing allegations about my Department.

I have discussed your letter with the Secretary of the Department. He rejects the allegations. He points out, however, that, where evidence of what you have alleged can be provided, the matters will be thoroughly investigated.

Also Marra Worra Worra feels it is being ignored by Victor Hunter because of their protests some time ago at the fact that he picked up a hitch hiker and took him to Wangkatjungka Community and told them they had to employ him as a mechanic, and the fact that the hitch hiker (Joel Slater) then absconded from Wangkatjungka with the community vehicle and over $5,000.00 in cash and it cost Wangkatjungka $2,000.00 to have him extradited from Sydney and to stand trial in Perth where he received 3 months jail and a $500.00 fine. No one knew anything about him and the day after he was caught by the police he had a ticket booked to go to America. He is a Canadian and was in Australia on a tourist visa.

Victor Hunter at the same time replaced Richard Scutt at Bayulu Community for 3 months, and since that time there has been nothing but trouble at Bayulu, and Richard Scutt has also drawn up his own contract which he has repeatedly asked the Chairman to sign.
This is really pathetic in the true sense of the word. In a pleading way the Chairman notes:

We also do not think we should have to pay the excess of $200.00 on the new bus we purchased that Victor Hunter drove up here at Christmas time and rolled over, as he has never told the Executive what happened he just arranged it all in Port Hedland and told us nothing, and we did not receive the bus until March.

What is important about that is that there seems to be a lack of discipline, control and input by the Department in relation to those sorts of matters. But the Department of Aboriginal Affairs' Cedric Wyatt wrote back-it is moving to read this-relating to the bus rolled over by the project officer in Derby:
The questions relating to the bus are I understand a private matter between yourselves and Mr Hunter and do not involve the Department.
Then he said:
As regards the future funding of MWW I must register my serious concern after the discrepancies and inefficiencies pointed out by your auditor and which have apparently yet to be rectified.

It took that organisation to complain about some very serious matters to which the Department was very sensitive before the Department sent back a letter of abuse threatening it with a withdrawal of its funds because it had complained about one of the project officers. That is the problem with this Government and with the Department at present: there is no management, there is no efficiency, there is no accountability, there is no concern, there is no care-and least of all is their compassion for the Aboriginal community. They are pawns in this game of black politics. These poor Aboriginal people are used in the long term for the benefit of these project officers, in some cases, and of the community officers, and at the end of the day they are lined up and convinced, because they know no better, to vote for the Labor Party. I find it sad and depressing; but more than anything else I find it an indictment of this Government, which shows no care and no compassion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there has been something like 15 hours of debate on this Bill, and from what I heard of it, a good deal of it was vapid nonsense. I do not propose to add any vapid nonsense to it. Therefore, I will be speaking for a very short time. However, I have just seen an amendment which is to be moved by the Opposition, I understand in Committee of the Whole, regarding the appropriations to parliamentary departments. It says that the Senate `reaffirms the resolution of 2 December' and so on, and `requires the Minister for Finance' to do this, that and so on. I repeat that this is not just a question of government policy. It is a question of the Constitution. The Senate does not determine its appropriations, nor does the House of Representatives, per se, determine its appropriations. Only Ministers of the Crown are constitutionally authorised to put requests to the Governor-General concerning the appropria- tion of money. So the Senate can carry as many resolutions as it likes.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. For the benefit of the Senate and the Minister, I point out that we are dealing with the second reading stage of the Appropriation Bills. The amendment to which the Minister is referring is to be moved in the committee stage.
—There is no point of order.

—I will be brief. As a matter of constitutional law, only the Executive, via the Parliament, can make requests to the Governor-General to appropriate money. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee, having considered the Eleventh Report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing,
(a) reaffirms the resolution of 2 December 1985 concerning the determination of the estimates of expenditure for the Senate to be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill;

(b) requires the Minister for Finance to process the Senate Department's estimates as early as practicable to enable any differences between the Minister and the Committee to be resolved in accordance with the resolution; and
(c) expects that the resolution will be adhered to in determining those estimates in the future.

We have just heard, at the end of the second reading debate on this Bill, an example of the typical standover tactics employed by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has told the Senate that he does not care what resolution is carried by this chamber, that he has no concern about what the wishes of this chamber of the Parliament are, that, as far as he is concerned, we can pass this motion over and over again and it will have no effect on him. I am not surprised that it will have no effect on him because he treats this Parliament with utter contempt. He treats the people of Australia with utter contempt. In the arrogant attitude he has expressed tonight he is simply maintaining a continuum of his normal style.

The Minister asserted that only the Executive can make a request of the Governor-General to appropriate money. That is no great, flashing blast of brilliance. The Opposition is well aware of that. The Minister will certainly recognise that this motion is not making a request of the Governor-General. We are requiring the Minister to process the Department of the Senate's estimates as early as practicable to enable any differences between the Minister and the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing to be resolved in accordance with the resolution.

If it is good enough for there to be a resolution of 2 December concerning the determination of the estimates of expenditure for the Senate to be included in this Bill, then surely it is good enough for the Senate to require one of its members to do the Senate's bidding. I am very concerned indeed about the nature of the arrogant assertion the Minister has made in this place on this matter. I certainly encourage the Australian Democrats to examine very closely what the Minister has said. I believe that this is a far more serious matter than, clearly, the Minister considers it to be. I believe that the threat he made to this chamber at the end of the second reading debate and his expression of contempt of the wishes of this chamber, if they are so expressed, are not simply a matter, as I said earlier, of arrogance but an attempt to take a view of the role of the Senate which is unacceptable to the Senate.

Whether the Senate believes that he is not bound by any requirement by it is a matter that he can look to, but if he believes that he has the right to dismiss entirely, to reject without discussion or any intellectual input, the desires of the Senate, he is setting off on a course which will bring about a serious collision between the Executive and the Parliament. I do not believe that the Minister has thought through his position. Any Minister in this place who decides to ignore a requirement by this chamber is adopting the sort of confrontationist approach which we keep hearing criticised by members of the Australian Labor Party who claim to be the great supporters of consensus.

All I am suggesting is that there are serious problems involved in the proposals about the parliamentary departments. Serious concerns have been expressed on our side-I think they are quite widespread-about the nature of the restructuring and so on. The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 gives us an opportunity to discuss these concerns. It seems vitally important that differences between the Minister and the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, as evidenced in the eleventh report of the Committee, should be resolved in accordance with the resolution referred to in my motion. Is the Minister saying that these matters should not be resolved in accordance with that resolution? I think it is vital for us to know whether the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying that decisions about expenditure will be made by the Executive.

—The Minister interjects that decisions about expenditure will be made by the Executive. I wonder why we go to the trouble of meeting in this place to approve the Estimates if in fact the Minister is saying that he does not give a damn what the view of the Senate is. As far as he is concerned, the all-powerful Executive will do whatever it wants to do. Quite frankly, this crystallises the attitude that has developed in this Government, that is, that it does not matter what the Parliament and the people want; it is what the Executive wants that dominates everything. This attitude dramatises the fact that this Government is out of touch. We have already seen in by-election results the extent to which the people of Australia are now regarding this Government as being out of touch.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is going to persist with this view that it does not give a damn what the Parliament says or thinks and it will do what the Executive wants in all matters, I can only say that, to a degree, the Opposition welcomes the evidence of such arrogance because it will speed the end of that Executive. The Minister's approach here tonight is simply a reflection of the style of government we have learnt to expect from a government that is certainly out of touch, from a Prime Minister who seems to take more notice of his rich mates than what the Parliament has to say and from a Minister for Finance who seems to run out of friends not only in Australia but certainly within his own Party.

All I am asking the Minister to do, and all this motion is asking the Minister to do, is to process the Senate Department's estimates as early as practicable to enable any differences between the Minister and the Committee to be resolved. What is wrong with that? I ask the Minister to approach this matter in the spirit of consensus that he and his Party have continually suggested is the basic motive behind all of their political activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved on behalf of the Opposition by my colleague and cousin, Senator Michael Baume. I do so with not much fire. When we raised this issue a year or so ago on the occasion of the establishment of a select committee by the Senate, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) asserted that the Executive controlled expenditure and put forward the same argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to the Committee that there has never been a resolution of the problem of the proper relationship between the Parliament and the Executive in relation to the funding of the Parliament. It seems that the Glorious Revolution of 1688, which led to the development of a basis for modern constitutional practice, failed to address this question. It did not resolve the question of the funding of parliament by the Executive. Australia, which has adopted the practice of the British Parliament, has not resolved this question.

The Minister has stated that the Parliament in regard to its funding is subservient to the Executive. He has given us the reasons why. The Minister is correct in saying that only the Executive can initiate a message to the Governor-General. But to state that as a fact does not resolve the problem. The problem is one of what should be the proper relationship between the Parliament and the Executive for the funding of the Parliament. I have said before in this place that there are several possible scenarios. One could have an unreasonable parliament that demands from the Executive too much money. One could have an unreasonable Executive that sought to bring a difficult parliament to heel.

In order to avoid what could be potentially a constitutional crisis of the greatest magnitude, some mechanism needs to be established to resolve once and for all this question of how the Parliament should be funded by the Executive. The Minister has stated accurately the position at the present time. I suggest to the Committee that that is an unsatisfactory position. It is only because of the commonsense of all parties that there has not been a crisis in the 88 years since Federation. It seems to me an absolute certainty that at some time in the future the Executive and the Parliament will have a major confrontation on this matter. I therefore join my colleague Senator Michael Baume in saying that we need to find a cooperative solution. If the Minister says that this is not the time to look for such a solution, I urge him to say to us that he will try to take on board the need to examine this question and establish a way in which this can be done.

In the time I have left, I want to raise one other matter which relates to the Executive and the Parliament. I intend to say very little during this debate on the appropriations legislation. I might take this opportunity to raise a matter that, to some extent, involves the Parliament. The provision of art works for the Parliament was raised during the consideration of the parliamentary departments. In fact, our Clerk, who is sitting in the advisers box, wrote a very important letter to the Committee indicating that the advice that had been given on this matter by the Parliament House Construction Authority was wrong in several quite important respects. Again, this is a problem created by executive practice. The Government withdrew some money from the budget provided for the furnishings of the new Parliament House. The Government made a judgment about the appropriate level of funding, and I do not question that decision. That was a decision for executive government. As a result of that funding withdrawal, the commissioning of art works had to be cut back and fewer art works were available for the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but who took them all?

—That is the very point I want to come to. The Executive, having decided that the art acquisition program should be cut back and that there should be fewer art works available, did not share in the consequences of that decision. It was awkward to obtain information because a couple of departments were involved. But during the examination of the estimates I asked for the list of art works that have been provided to Ministers and office holders. Of course, after they were provided with art works honourable senators were then allowed to choose two art works for their own offices. Some might say that that is more than we are entitled to, more than we deserve or more than we can usefully appreciate. But let us put that question to one side.
—How many did the big fellows get?

—That is most interesting. The list that I received showed that some of the Ministers or office-holders received 25 art works or more. Some of them have very large suites to furnish. I understand that there are many walls for the art works to go on. You, Mr President, actually received 25, I think. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) received more. The Leader of my Party received almost the same number.
—Order! The President is not the one in the chair; I am.

—I was referring to him, Mr Chairman, not as the Chairman but as the occupant of the suite which received 25 art works. Many of the Ministers received 15 art works or more. I just want to make the point that the Executive, having made the decision to reduce the program-it may have been a perfectly correct decision-should have shared more obviously, visibly and publicly in the consequences of that decision. It did not do so. Not only that, but certain of the art works were not to be made available to private senators and members. If one goes to the offices of some of the most senior people in the Parliament, one sees not only works on the walls of their offices but some very nice ceramics in their offices as well. I can advise the Committee that private senators and members are not to be allowed to be issued with ceramics. No doubt people are concerned that, while they may be safe in the offices of Prime Ministers and leaders, they are not safe in the offices of private senators and members.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that I am extremely grateful to a Canberra potter who, having heard of this plight on radio, came in and provided my office with two splendid pots. Of course I will provide my own art works to make up the number, and I am able to cope. But we have these two problems which involve the relationship between the Executive and the Parliament. Senator Michael Baume raised the first issue. I just remind the Minister that this is a continuing problem and sooner or later it will cause a constitutional crisis of the greatest magnitude. I suggest, in a spirit of amity really, that we establish a mechanism for trying to address and resolve this problem. I invite the Minister to consider that next time the Government cuts some program of provision for the Parliament the consequences might be shared equally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, he or she who holds the purse strings calls the tune. There has been one exception to that, and that has been, as I understand it, the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The reason for that is that we are all committed to the interests of parliamentary democracy, and because we are all committed to the interests of parliamentary democracy and to maintaining the separation of powers enshrined in the Commonwealth Constitution between the Executive and the Parliament we have all understood that it is the right, indeed the duty, of both the Executive and the Parliament to ensure that sufficient funds are available for the proper functioning of this Parliament, whether it be the Senate or the House of Representatives or associated services.

SPEECH.PARA: We are the elected members of the people of Australia. We have been charged by the people of Australia to undertake certain functions. Those functions are representative functions and audit and control functions. We heard an example of that today when it was revealed that, although there has been an instruction by the Executive Government that there should be some tightening of belts in the area of the acquisition of art works for Parliament House, we see now, because of questions that have been asked in Estimates committee hearings as part of our audit and control function, that the Executive Government is not tightening its belt.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like Mr Hawke with Kirribilli House.

—Presumably that is another matter about which questions were asked at an Estimates committee hearing at which I was not present. I must say that I am sorry that Senator Walsh has made the statement that he has made tonight, because it has broken the unwritten law that has existed between successive executive governments and parliaments over the years. I was sorry to see that he did not take advantage of my point of order and continued in the second reading debate to address himself to the motion proposed by the Opposition in respect of the Appropriations (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the motion which is now before us. Had he ceased to make these comments it would have enabled Senator Michael Baume to move this motion and advance his arguments in support of it. I think that they were perfectly reasonable arguments, couched in conciliatory terms.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not one of us in this chamber who is not seized with the importance of cutting down on expenditure. As a member of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, I can assure the Minister that that is the fact. The Minister does not need assurance from me; presumably he has the assurance of the Government representatives on that Committee. They know as well as I do that we really carve the expenditure right down to the bone. In fact, extreme difficulty is likely to be experienced if a further adjustment is not made to the finances available for essential services to senators. Of course I cannot speak for members of the House of Representatives, because that is another area and it would not be appropriate or proper for me to do so.

I do not wish to go into the correspondence that has presumably been the basis of this motion. As matter of fact, I did not know that this motion was to be moved, I must say. But, having read it, I am in favour of it and will vote for it. I hope that the Minister sees his way clear not to retract but somehow to smooth over the words that he has uttered tonight. That statement is constitutionally correct, as has been indicated, but whether or not it is constitutionally correct is beside the point. If we are committed to parliamentary democracy, surely the Minister for Finance, who holds the purse strings, must be the first to recognise that, and he must recognise it publicly by way of a statement to this chamber. Unless he does so, I am afraid we will be on a collision course with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to knock back the Appropriation Bills? Is that what you are threatening?

—I do not think that that would be an appropriate way of going about the matter. I hope that wiser counsel will prevail and that once this motion is carried, as I hope it will be, the Minister will have regard to the resolution and to his responsibility as a member of the Senate.
—As a member of the Government.
—I was hoping that the Minister would not say that, because the Minister is a member of this chamber as well as being a member of the Government.
